I am enclosing applications for admission of Nelson Albert Starr and Henry Lester Starr to the Gordon Jeffrey Residential School at Edmonton.

Renora R.C. Indian School,
May 11, 1946

Mr. Norman Patterson,
Agent,
Renora Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re: Stella Itiponikwek

In the matter of information regarding the leave of Stella from this school I would like to quote the recommendation contained in X-Ray return from Fort William Sanatorium as November 11, 1946 a few days prior to this pupil's departure from the school.

"Diagnosis: Minimum pulmonary Tuberculosis, active."
"Recommendation: Should be admitted to Sanatorium immediately."

As she was active tuberculosis we have informed the parents of the diagnosis and the recommendation, stressing on the excellent prospects for recovery as well.

There was room at Fort William at the time.

After consultation with the chief of his reserve the father of the child informed us that it was his intention to take his child home and cure her with indian medicine.

In Sept. 1947 the father of the child told us that she was well again and that he would take her in any time. We told him to do so as she was still and still is on the school list. He was to bring Victor in too.

He told him that they would be both X-rayed as soon as they would come, he hasn't brought them.

Thus our amazement of hearing about their admission in Cecilia Jeffray.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: Margaret (Stella) Potawatikweh,
121 Rat Portage Band.

Receipt is hereby acknowledged of your
129-3-10 (E.1) of the 4th instant regarding the
admittance of the above to the Cecilia Jeffrey
Indian Residential School.

With reference to your last paragraph this girl
was admitted to the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential
School on June 8th 1942., and has not been discharged
from the latter school.

On November 11th 1946., she was recommended to
admission to a sanatorium and was taken home by her
parents on November 14th 1946., and has been home since
that time.

Attached hereto is a letter from the Principal of the
Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School.

Norman Paterson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency

C.
May 26, 1948.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Kenora, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 13th instant,
file 105-13A, with reference to Margaret Petmanikweb.

It is noted that this girl was regularly
admitted to the Kenora Residential School and was only
allowed to leave the school due to the fact that she
required medical treatment. When her condition
improved she should have been returned to the Kenora
School.

In view of sub-section two of section ten
of the Indian Act and the further fact that the girl
had never been discharged from the Kenora School, the
principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School should never
have accepted her. He should, therefore, be instructed
to return the girl at once as no grant will be allowed
for her at Cecilia Jeffrey.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Re: Transportation of pupils leaving and returning

In connection with the summer holidays we would
request that an amount of $50.00 be allowed for the
transportation of pupils whose parents are unable to
provide the cost of transportation.

I would recommend that an amount of $50.00 be
authorized for the children of the Cecilia Jeffrey
Indian Residential School and $50.00 for the children
of the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential School.

Norman Paterson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
June 15, 1948.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Kenora, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, file 106-11, the Department will allow an amount of $50.00 towards the cost of transportation of pupils going on holidays from the Cecilia Jeffrey School this year.

A similar amount for the same purpose will be allowed the Kenora school.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

In forwarding to you this application for the admission of Leslie Bandamin to this school, I realise that some explanation is in order. The child is much younger than he should be for admission to a residential school.

This boy is an illegitimate child. The mother has married a man other than the boy's father. This man, her present husband, seems to have difficulty in living peaceably with the child. In fact the presence of the child threatens to break up what may otherwise prove to be a reasonably satisfactory home.

By admitting this child to this school we can give him a chance to exist without provoking strife, and we can assist his mother and step-father. That he was not receiving good care is evidenced by the fact that he was brought here from hospital, where he had been treated for severe frost-bites on both hands.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE ROBBY (TEN)

I am writing to confirm information given to you verbally about Bobby. He returned to this school on May 14th and asked my advice about the possibility of his returning to High School next year. We discussed the reasons for his having left school after only a few weeks of attendance last fall, and I learned that he had felt really handicapped when starting High School, for two reasons. Like many students of Indian Residential Schools his knowledge of English is not such as to be desired, and he felt handicapped when he began to work among English-speaking pupils. Then too he had had only half days in classroom while taking his Grade VIII, and did not feel that he had the thorough grounding in the work which the average day school student, attending classes all of each school day, had acquired.

I suggested to him that he return to this school and study with our Grade VIII class, in order that he might be well prepared to return to High School here in the fall. This he has done. He is studying well, is really trying to improve his English, and in so many ways given real promise of proving a good student who will take full advantage of the opportunity to carry on at school.

May I ask that he be re-admitted to this school, in order that money grant may be paid for him during this period (commencing April 14th, 1949).

Sincerely yours,

Dear Father Renaud,

Before he left Ottawa Father Plourde spoke to me about Nancy and Josephine McDonald. These girls attended the Kenora Residential School to June 30, 1950 but Father Plourde was informed that they had been placed in the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School after the summer holidays.

As they had been regularly admitted to the Kenora Residential School and were eligible for admission to that school I wrote the Superintendent instructing him to have the children returned to the Kenora school.

In a letter dated December 1, Superintendent Paterson advises me that the girls returned to the Kenora school on November 9th. I thought you would like to have this information on file.

Yours sincerely,

Re: Guy Hunter, Illington Band
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Res. School

The above noted pupil ran away from the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School on January 27th, 1951. His brother was in town at the time and had sent Guy back to the school by bus but he evidently returned to town in the same bus. From then up to the present no contact has been made with him nor has any of our Indian pupils or people seen the boy.

Extensive search has been made both by the Principal, the writer, local police, R.C.M.P., Police and Ontario Provincial Police who had been given a description of the boy. The boy's father and brother also have tried to make contact by visiting different woods contractor's camps.

A letter from the Principal, Mr. Ross has been received advising of the continued absence of this boy, and a copy of this letter is attached for your information.

Boys and girls have left the school before and after a considerable lapse of time have been eventually found or have returned voluntarily and it is possible in this case that someone is sheltering him and is not coming through with information.

We shall continue our efforts to trace this boy. The wood camps are just about to break up within the next 10 days or so and it may be possible to make more thorough enquiries.

Norman Paterson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

Mr. N. Paterson,

With reference to the September Quarterly Return for the Caelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, it is noted that the Principal has dropped several of the pupils' names who were on the June Quarter.

Would you kindly advise the Principal that before he drops any names from the Return he should request the approval of their discharge. This can be done by showing the names on the discharge section of Form I.A. 411. On receipt of this list, the Department will advise you whether the discharges are approved.

The Principal has claimed thirty days grant for pupils 0367, 0368, 401, 402, 403 and 404; while under column "Date of Entrance to School" he shows that these children entered after September 1, consequently we have reduced the amount of grant in each case accordingly.

It is noted that there are some pupils carried on the return who have been absent for as long as three years. Will you kindly advise the Principal to apply for the discharge of pupils who he feels will not return to school within the next year. Should any of the pupils return to school at a later date, he may apply for re-admissions which are usually granted.
In following the present practice of carrying children on the Return who are actually not at school and will probably be away for some time, the enrolment is shown as higher than it actually is. We are anxious to keep our records as accurate as possible when compiling statistics.

Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mrs Patterson:

Re Basil Green, Pencil Lake 32, 1/3.

As you know Basil Green is again with us. He was discharged from Brandon Sanatorium on August 30, and was sent on to us at C. J. School with a letter of introduction to Dr. Playfair. He has to report for photoperiodic pupils every week for ten days for at least another year, probably two years.

Following our several conversations on him I think we concluded that considering all factors it would be best for Basil to continue on at C. J. and attend Kenora High school. Mrs. Richmond, principal of C. J., B., has arranged a time table for Basil and he is now attending classes there. Since school is already underway we thought it best to reduce delay to a minimum in settling his status.

Basil was admitted to C. J. School in May 1948, but there remains the matter of his discharge which appears in our records as "in care," unlikely to return to school" (Admission - Discharge form attached to Quarterly Returns, March 31, 1952).

His discharge was approved under the date of April 27th, (file 461-10) as pupil number 265. Inasmuch as Kenora seems to be the only centre at which Basil can receive the medical attention which he requires, without entailing undue strain etc., due to weekly travel, and since school has already been in session for almost a fortnight, could you take whatever steps may be necessary to grant us authority to re-admit the child to Cecilia Jeffrey?

Ottawa, November 21, 1953.

Rev. Rosaline John

This family is from the Kenora Agency in the Province of Ontario. The mother is dead. In September 1947, Joe John, Rosaline's grandfather, who had custody of the child at that time, signed an application for her admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey (Presbyterian) Indian Residential School, indicating on the application that the religious denomination was "Indian belief".

In view of this information, Rosaline's admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey School was approved and she was admitted as a grant-earning pupil on September 25, 1949.

Rosaline John has been at the Cecilia Jeffrey School continuously from September 25, 1949 to June 30, 1951. In September 1951, the father, Alex John when returning Rosaline to school from summer vacation assumed that she was attending the Kenora R.C. School as he placed her there. When it was established that she had previously attended the Cecilia Jeffrey School she was returned to that school in October 1951 and has remained there since.

Since his wife's death the father, Alex John has remarried and requests the transfer of his daughter from the Cecilia Jeffrey (Presbyterian) Indian Residential School to the Kenora (Roman Catholic) Indian Residential School by statutory declaration reading as follows:
"I and my wife desire to have my child, Rosaline born February 15th, 1941 attend the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School, in Kenora, Ontario, we are both of the Roman Catholic Faith and wish Rosaline to be trained in the same Faith."

Father A. Lacelle, now Principal of the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School, writes regarding the religious denomination of the mother and Rosaline:

"I recall attending Rosaline's mother on her death bed in 1941 and hearing her pleading with me that Rosaline be baptised and raised in her faith. She had entered the hospital a few days earlier with gallbladder trouble and had asked for baptism which she received on the 16th of February.

Alex is now married to Mary Rose Seymour and is bound by the usual engagement for mixed marriages to have his children raised in the Catholic faith, which promises are signed by two witnesses on January 24th. This, of course, does not apply to Rosaline, but the mother's plea and the child's faith, and the instances of her grandfather Joe John to put her in the Catholic School would justify my letter as he is the guardian of the child."

Rosaline was baptised on February 19, 1941 according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church. A copy of "Certificate of baptism" is attached.

It would be appreciated if a ruling were given on Alex John's request.

Director,

[Signature]

M.F./H.M.
Ottawa, December 19, 1952.

Mr. H. Paterson,
Bupt. Indian Agency,
Kenora, Ontario.

The request for the transfer of Rosaline John from the Cecilia Jeffrey to the Kenora Indian Residential School has been received and carefully considered. The following ruling has been made:

"The parent is of the Roman Catholic Faith and apparently so is Rosaline consequently she should attend a Roman Catholic school."

In view of the above ruling the Department approves the transfer of the child from the Cecilia Jeffrey school to the Kenora school as a grant-earning pupil.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re: December Quarterly Return,

Ref. your letter File No. 129/23-16-461(A2), of January 22nd, and in answer to the request for additional information re December Quarterly Return as indicated in the copy forwarded to me of the letter of Mr. Phelan, dated at Ottawa, January 19, 1953.

First replying in general to the question asked: In our Return the term "Ill" has been employed to indicate that the child in question has been sent to bed for the time indicated either in the dormitory, or in the infirmary ward, at school. For example, pupil # 285 was an ex-sam patient. For three and a half days during the quarter he was ill; feeling well enough to go to classes, and was in bed at the school. He was taken to St. Joseph's hospital for check-up and tests, and was in hospital for two days, after which he returned to Brandon Jan. Total days for illness are thus 5½ days. In our Return, the terms "Hospital" or "In Hospital," indicate that the pupil was admitted to St. Joseph's Hospital, Kenora, on Doctor's orders for the period indicated. The term "Infirmary" indicates that the child was confined to bed in the ward at the school. In our Return, the term "Visiting" means that the child is out of the classroom for the period stated, and that during that time he was with his parents, usually in the building. At a school such as this, occasions arise where parents who have come very long distances, and who may see their children only once during the school term, arrive near the end to see the children. In such cases we allow the child to "Visit" with the parents in the girls' or boys' playing-room, say, for the afternoon, while the pupils are here. On occasion the parent may be given permission to take the child to town for the afternoon, in which case the child is back in residence before suppertime that evening. In all cases, without exception, such "Visits" are made with their children are with permission of the Principal, and are allowed only under special circumstances where long distances and other factors are involved. We have been most scrupulous in reporting all cases of absenteeism without permission under the category "A.W.O.L."
Conversely, and by inference, all other cases of absenteeism are with the full knowledge and permission of the principal.

Pupil # 307 was ill, in bed, in the dormitory, at the school; period of illness obviously one day, since the full quota of days in the classroom for any single pupil for the quarter was fifty-six, and none of which he spent fifty-five in the classroom. Pupil # 359 has a best known record, remarks self-explanatory; discharge applied for this quarter. Pupil # 377, the same as pupil # 307. Pupil # 346 was hospitalized two days, St. Joseph's, Kenora. Pupil # 346 was in hospital in June, 1952, did not return to school until after the New Year, 1953. Pupil # 346 was in school, fifty-six and one half days out of the quota of fifty-six. Pupil # 346 was allowed to visit with his parents during school hours on October 29th., the one half day they were in the area. This was with the knowledge and permission of the principal, and the child was not away from the premises. Pupil # 346 was absent without leave for twelve days during the quarter. He ran away. On another occasion he was allowed to visit with his parents in the children's playroom at the school, with permission of the principal, for one afternoon, during school hours. Pupil # 347 ran away one afternoon, was brought back to school the same evening. Pupil # 348 was ill in bed, in the ward, at the school for one and one half days during the quarter. Pupil # 349 was absent without leave for one day during the quarter after he returned to school at the end of the term. The same applies to Pupil # 352, and Pupil # 353, and to Pupil # 370. Pupil # 379 was hospitalized for tests and observation on December 3rd., (St. Joseph's, Kenora), and was sent to Brandon San on December 7th., 1952. Pupil # 395 was discharged as an incorrigible run-away, a nuisance, and a disturbing influence. Ref. Department File # 461-10 (EO) under date of January 15, 1953. Pupil # 396 was ill, in bed, at the school for one day during the quarter. Pupil # 397 was allowed to sight with his parents for one afternoon, during school hours, with the principal's permission. I believe I allowed the father to take the child to town that afternoon. The date was October 29th., Remarks re Pupil # 349 are self-explanatory. Pupil # 405 ran away and was absent without permission for five days during the quarter. Pupil # 406 was absent without permission for one and one half days, also pupil # 408. The latter was treated at St. Joseph's Hospital, Kenora, and at the school infirmary for eight days, for a skin disease. He was admitted to St. Joseph's on November 12th., and discharged on November 19th. Pupil # 411 had a type of jaundice, and was in bed in the ward, at the school, for nine days during the quarter. Pupil # 413 was absent without leave for seven days during the quarter, and spent seven and one half days in St. Joseph's Hospital, Kenora, where he underwent extensive tests and observation as a T.B. suspect. He was admitted to the hospital on November 12th., and discharged on November 19th. Pupil # 416 was
visiting with his parents, out of the classroom, but within the school and with permission of the principal for most of one day during the quarter. The date was October 23rd. He is a new pupil at the school, and this was his only opportunity to see his people during the quarter. Pupil #417 was ill in bed, in the dormitory, at the school, for one half day during the quarter. Pupil #418, the same as pupil #406 and #405, was run away all three together, and were returned after one and one half days. Pupil #420 was absent without permission for one day during the quarter. He was ill for eighteen days, twelve of which he spent in St. Joseph's Hospital, Kenora, and the remaining six days of which he spent in bed, in the ward, at the school. He was admitted to St. Joseph's on November 13th., and discharged on November 25th.

Pupil #0257 was ill, in bed, one half days, seven of which she spent in St. Joseph's Hospital, Kenora, the remainder in bed, in the ward, at the school. She was admitted to St. Joseph's on November 19th., and discharged on November 25th. Pupil #0259 was absent from the classroom for one half day during the quarter. She had been sick since October 17th. Pupil #0339 was ill at school, in the ward, October 6th., p.m., until October 17th. She was admitted to St. Joseph's Hospital, Kenora, for tests and observation of December 18th., and was discharged on December 19th. Pupil #0341 was ill at school four half days during the quarter - November 12, 14, 20, and 26. Pupil #0341 was ill for one half day during the quarter November 17th., inclusive. Pupil #0341 was ill at school, and was allowed on October 14, 15, 16. She was ill again, at school for one half day on October 20th., and again for one half day on November 8th. She was also ill for one half day on October 21st. She was in bed, in the ward, at the school, with infectious Hepatitis on November 17th., to dist. inclusive. This pupil was not hospitalized during the quarter. Pupil #0351 was ill at school, in the dormitory, on November 17th., inclusive. Pupil #0353 was ill for five days at school, in the ward, with Jaundice November 17th., to 21st., inclusive. Pupil #0354 and Pupil #0355 were each absent one half day, October 7th. They were allowed to spend this half day with their parents, out of the classroom, but within the confines of the school. Pupil #0356 was ill for one half day, in the dormitory, at the school, October 21st. Pupil #0360 was absent from the classroom with permission of the principal, to see her parents, on December 11th. She did not leave the school grounds. Pupil #0361 was allowed by the principal to leave the classroom for the afternoon of December 11th., to see her parents at the school, November 18th to 21st., inclusive, she was in bed, at school with Jaundice. Pupil #0365 missed one day of school, on October 20th. She was absent with permission of the principal, on October 21st., for one half of that day, but remained on the school property, and for the remaining half day she was permitted to go to town with her parents. Pupil #0366 was ill with Jaundice, in bed, in the ward, at the school, on December 1st., and 2nd., and for one half day on December 3rd. Pupil #0372 was ill from the afternoon on October 6th., until she returned to class on the morning of November 4th. She was sent to bed for rest on the afternoons of November 4th., and 5th. The child had Jaundice, but was not hospitalized. Pupil #0373 was hospitalized...
at St. Joseph's on the afternoon of October 2nd., and was discharged on October 6th. She was in bed, in the ward, at the school until she returned to the classroom on the morning of November 4th. She rested on the afternoons of November 4th. and 5th., as did Pupil # 0372. Pupil 0374, the same as pupil # 416. Pupil # 0375 was another case of infectious hepatitis. She was sick from October 15th. to November 14th. She was in bed, in the ward, at the school, and was not hospitalized. She was out of the classroom all day on October 15th., and one half day on October 16th.

She was in the classroom all day on October 17th., and one half day on October 20th. She was in bed, in the ward, at the school, from October 21st. to November 11th. She was in the classroom on the afternoons of November 13th. and 14th. and rested in bed at the school on the afternoons of these three days. (Periodic sore eyes). Pupil # 0376, the same as pupil # 392, except that the girl was admitted to school a few days late as indicated.

I trust that this letter provides the information desired by the Department, and that the requested grant will be allowed for the pupils in question. If a more exhaustive search of our records is essential, we shall try to find the time to make it. I would suggest, however, that the Department might find it feasible to issue some kind of detailed directive with official abbreviations for the convenience of principals who are attempting to supply accurate information in the blank spaces available on the Quarterly Return. The Department's illustrative data March 31st., 1953, is helpful, but complete standardization of terminology would seem to me to be the answer to many of the difficulties experienced by both the Department and principals reporting.

Our copy of Dr. Phelan's letter to you, dated January 19th., 1953, leaves us in some doubt as to whether retroactive grant should be claimed only for pupils # 342 and # 392. We have no indication either as to whether the grant for pupils # 346, 0361, 0365 and 0376 is in doubt for reasons similar to those given for pupils # 342 and 392. Since Form No. I.A.403 does not provide space on which to claim retroactive grant, we are claiming this form for the pupils specifically mentioned, that is pupils # 342 and 392, on an additional sheet of Form No. I.A.403. If grant has been withheld for any of the other pupils who may be in question, presumably the Department will allow this grant on the basis of information supplied in this letter.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Enclosed are the required number of copies of the Quarterly Returns quarter ending March 31, 1953, rewritten as per your request by letter of May 16, 1953, ref. you file 129/23-14-461(A1).

The Department, as you quote, has taken the liberty of changing the dates of return of pupils in the original return submitted for this quarter as indicated in your letter of date as above.

To the best of my knowledge and belief we received no departmental or other directive indicating the date of school opening in January, and having to assume something, assumed that children should be considered late if they had not returned to school by Monday, January 5th, rather than Thursday, January 1st. This, you will remember our checking with your office. It seems evident from the changes made in our report in Ottawa in the remarks column under, for example pupils #0353 and 0360 &c., etc., that the Department considers a child to have been a day late if he was not in school on January 1st. The directive on Preparation of Quarterly Returns dated March 9, 1953 indicates that the dates of return of pupils are to be noted in the remarks column of Form 1.A.403. The original form submitted to your office indicated such dates, and have been revised with most of these dates changed. Assuming that the Department has in mind some definite date for the beginning of terms, it is understandable that we are in error regarding the number of days a pupil is to be considered late on returning to school. On the other hand, what I do not understand is how the actual date itself may be changed. For example, it is known to us at this school that pupil #31 returned to residence here on January 6th, 1953, and not on January 2nd., as the corrected form would indicate. In the re-written form herewith submitted, we have claimed this date of January 6th., and not attempt to indicate how many days the pupil is to be considered late. On the other hand, in the re-written form we have claimed 74 days for this pupil rather than 69 as in the original form submitted. We have followed this same procedure in all cases in the re-written form. I can assure you that there was no intention on our part of claiming more grant for any pupil than is allowable. The
fundamental error seems to have been in assuming that pupils in residence up to Christmas are allowed their grant for the full holiday period as they are over the summer holidays if they are in residence during the quarter which ends June 30. The Quarterly Return, as corrected in Ottawa, would seem to indicate that holidays ended on December 31. The form as re-written claims grant on this basis.

We have included the claim for retroactive grant on a separate sheet as was done originally, and hope that this is as it should be.

The returned form as corrected states that pupil # 368 is overcharged 65 days. Please note that this pupil was not absent without leave from January 26 to the end of the quarter, but for one half day only on January 26th., as originally indicated. He was in the classroom for fifty-six and one half days during the quarter. We originally claimed for him 86 days in the "Residence" column, considering him four days late because he did not return to residence until January 9. The re-written form claims for him 81 days in residence.

Pupils # 303, 335, 407, 413, 420, and 0257 were in residence over the whole holiday period. Please note also that in the corrected form two days have been deducted from pupil # 392 reducing his total for the quarter from 90 to 88 days. This pupil was out of residence for the two days indicated as "visiting" but with his parents here and with the permission of the principal. The child was merely allowed to leave the classroom for a few hours to spend a little time with his folk when they visited here. This seems to me quite permissible. We report all cases of pupils out of residence without permission even for one half day under the category "AWOL".

I wonder if it would not be possible for principals to be supplied with specific instructions at least once a year giving the number of days in the school year, the number of days in each quarter, the dates of beginning and ending of holiday periods, etc., so that these do not have to be deduced from vague sources? I trust that these forms as re-written will not be the cause of further inconvenience to you, and that they meet with requirements.

Yours very truly,

J. Eldon Andrews,
Principal.

With reference to your letter of June 17th regarding the March Quarterly Return for the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, we have carefully reviewed the return and are forwarding it to the Chief Treasury Officer to make full Per Capita Grant payment on the March Quarter.

There are a number of points which we would like the Principal to be aware of for his guidance in preparing future returns:

(a) It is the Department's usual practice to pay Per Capita Grant for the day a child enters a residential school. If a child enters school on January 3rd, he is allowed for eighty-six days during that quarter, providing the pupil is in residence full time, following his Return. When a pupil returns on February 1st, the school would be entitled to fifty-nine days grant. It is noted that the Principal on completing the March Return did not follow this practice.

(b) It is not necessary for the Principal to disallow grant for a pupil who was out of residence for one-half day. He may claim
grant for the full day. This is allowed due to the fact that the School Management is making provision for a pupil on the assumption that he will be in school for the full day.

(c) When a pupil is in residence he is allowed to leave his classroom in the morning or afternoon or for a whole day to visit his parents who are visiting the school. Grant should be disallowed when pupils are away from residence for a whole day.

(d) The Principal has requested that the Department advise all principals of the number of days in each quarter. We do not see any necessity for doing so as the number of days can be worked out simply by adding the number of days for the three months in the particular quarter.

Attached I am forwarding you two copies of the latest regulations regarding completing the quarterly returns. I expect they will be of benefit both to yourself and the Principal of the Coe Hill Jeffrey Residential School. Two copies of this letter are being forwarded to you in order that you may send one to the Principal.

July 28, 1953.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

In reply to your letter of July 21, your file #129/23-16-481(Al) with reference to application for discharge of the above-noted pupil as referred to in your letter from the Superintendent of Education, dated July 13, reference #631-10 (Ed). We have been attempting to clear the Quarterly Return of children who for one reason or another do not seem likely to return to school, or who have been out of school over extended periods of time, or who, as in the case of the child in question here, have sometimes appeared to us as cases where a school of this type is not very adequately equipped to handle. In doing this I have tried in each case to consider all the factors involved, and to strive at a wise decision always with the needs and best interests of the child in view. The decision which I had reached in the case of Tom Ross was not an easy one to make at the time, and has continued to do so ever since. I am glad to have this case re-opened for further consideration in the hope that some more effective methods of dealing with truant children may be brought into operation within the next year or so.

We at this school, by the very nature of our work, welcome the opportunity to work with problem children in order to do what we can to expand their horizons and to help to lead them into a better and fuller life. However, while it is obvious that we are primarily an educational rather than a reform institution and only a certain proportion of our energies can go into the tracking down of truant children without causing many others to suffer neglect.

I have repeatedly stated my considered conviction that the problem of truancy in this area can be dealt with successfully in the long run through an impartial third party not directly connected either with the school or the Indian agency in the person of a full-time truant officer. In every single case of truancy
Since our arrival at this school we as a staff have made every effort humanly possible to retrieve the child. Sometimes we are successful; sometimes we are not. I myself have spent as many as three consecutive days and nights with very little sleep in the bush and on the roads exhausting every possibility of retrieving children in the fear that some harm might come to them. We make it a policy never to give up the search until some definite indication is received that the child is safe or returned. The nature of the terrain in this area and the inadequacy of the resources, lack of specialized means of transportation and travel grants, and other factors make it impossible for school staffs and the Indian Superintendent, nevertheless, to combat this problem alone. There is no denying the fact that the problem of truancy in this area is a serious one though its effects are out of all proportion to its extent and frequency. A single truant child is capable of producing a situation in a school community which can operate for months and may be seriously disrupted for days on end.

The problem of truancy among Indian children needs thorough and sympathetic study as all of us know. It bears little resemblance to the sporadic kind of truancy which occurs among white children and involves difficulties which are not found in the latter. In only a comparatively small number of cases does truancy among Indian children seem to have causes which can be analysed and dealt with by ordinary methods. The causes which are cause enough to be the face that Indian children are aware of the times of year when parents are leaving for the rice fields, trap lines, hunting expeditions and so forth, and also when they move toward the town to buy and sell and so on. Children at these times become unsettled and may make determined and persistent efforts to catch up with parents before they get away. The fact that has to be reckoned with is that there are children who will run away from school even if the factors like cold water, ice, distance, lack of food and so on are no deterrent. There is also a factor of irrationality involved in this matter of truancy. There is no necessary connection between conditions at the school, for example, and the fact that a child runs away. It is usually fruitless to reason that the event has a cause in our sense of the term and that if the cause is removed the condition may be corrected. The whole problem of truancy in this area seems to me to be important enough to warrant some intensive research by a special commission set up for the purpose.

I consider myself fortunate in having come to this work with some sociological and anthropological background, and I feel competent to say that, from our own cultural standpoint, the causes of truancy appear to be basically primitive in nature and need careful and scientific investigation from a broad anthropological basis. Notions which might be described as "small or bad seasons," the bush, and so forth, have a bearing on this problem. Phases of the moon have something to do with it as well as crisp frosty weather. Childish reasons such as "the boys were teasing us" are quite adequate from the child's point of view to justify his starting out on a fifty to one hundred mile trek in sub-zero weather with no provision for food or shelter and, considering the
journey, inadequately clothed.

Of the specific negative factors contributing to this whole problem I think that the lack of well-equipped playgrounds and the shortage of playground space and facilities rank foremost. The fairly general disinterest shown as to the value to the Indian of education in the white man's sense, and the consequent inability of Indian schools to also be major positive factors. A look at the problem of playground space alone will serve to illustrate the point. There are at present two playgrounds, one for boys and one for girls, outside the small patch of playing ground four feet by four feet that is allowed per child. More important than this is the fact that, come weather or example, children from six to sixteen years of age are crowded into so small an area. Outside of the classroom there is no possibility of really separating the younger from the older children during any single hours of the day. Younger children are subjected to bullying, while the older children have always the little ones under their feet. Perhaps the most obvious complaint of Indian parents is that the older children are hard on the little ones. Certainly the common reaction given by children to running away from school is that some other child has hurt them.

This does not indicate that older Indian children are prone to beat up on the little ones, but precisely the opposite. It is true that Indians generally are uncommonly solicitous of children, and that the Indian child is commonly a pampered child in our own eyes. Nevertheless all of this reflects a situation which could be corrected at this school only by a radical expansion of staff facilities and eventually by doubling the number of supervising personnel, playgrounds and playgrounds. I believe that supervision here is inadequate as it could possibly be under the circumstances. The circumstances, however, tend to create a situation in which it is less to impossible for the supervisor to give individual attention to seventy-five children of varying ages and the attention he individually which is their right. This amounts to pre-adolescent children need the kind of care, play activity and human contact that they receive if they are to develop into the well-balanced personality for which the type of educational opportunities offered by a school of this type ought to prepare. As the situation is now, even if one of the best instructors is given the kind of attention she could demand which is due her, the other is necessarily relegated to the extent. It is not possible for a single supervisor who is working in the room and play ground at his disposal to adequately care for children in normal activity out of school hours when their ages range from six to sixteen. The problem of properly fenced grounds is also indicated, related to the problem of bullying. As the situation is at present any child who may wish to do so may merely lace into the bush at will, and it is fair manner to say from her to supervisors that a situation of continuous tension should have to exist over this matter.

While I realize that there is much more to be said on this subject, and that the opinions stated were hardly asked for in your letter, but
are to be regarded as my own, I think that this letter does
indicate that this is a problem which we here do not take lightly,
and points to a few things which may be of some value in future
considerations of this problem as a whole. In the case of pupil
Tom Ross, I would like to reverse my own former decision and
ask that his application for acceptance be withdrawn, and at the
same time request that he return to school in September to con-
tinue his education. I should like also to assure you that we for
our part will not relax our efforts to do what we can toward the
solution of this whole problem.

Very sincerely yours,

(Signed) J. Eldon Andrews,

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of 6th inst., I wish to state that I had already discussed this matter with Capt. Edwards and his views were the same as suggested in my letter. He was absent on Treaty when I wrote and will be another four or five days.

I might say I have written different live-stock breeders' associations also the Agricultural College at Winnipeg and at Guelph, and the only encouraging letter I received was from Guelph. I am becoming alarmed at our situation here as with the opening of school in September we will be without milk.

The cows which Mr. Macdonald has are poor milkers. It takes the five of them milking at their best to give the present animal only a limited supply. Then there will be a period of almost three months where these cows will be dry. Further these cows are not likely to be bred owing to the fact that the bull died.

My idea was to have 12 good milkers coming in at different times so that a steady supply of milk could be maintained. I would also like to have an additional 12 head of young cattle coming on so that the herd may be kept up. I would like to raise our own beef and make our own butter. It is much cheaper to get into

Dear Sir,

On the 8th instant I reported to the Sergeant in charge of the Mounted Police that I had received reports to the effect that liquor was being taken to the Indians on the Lake of the Woods and asked him to investigate the matter. Owing to the Police not having a large enough boat and owing to the Departmental officers being away, packed up for the Winter, I got in touch with Mr. Evans, Principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey School and borrowed the school boat for the use of the Police. The Sergeant took with him Constable Patterson of the Provincial Police, and a mechanic but their investigations did not lead to anything. In the afternoon of the 14th they were returning to Kenora when something went wrong with the clutch and they were unable to make the boat go. A wind sprung up and they were washed ashore on one of the islands. They had a canoe with them and were able to reach the camp, and returned to Kenora on the 15th and reported the matter to me. There had been a strong wind blowing on the night of the 14th and they did not know how badly the boat was damaged. I got in touch with the Lake of the Woods Milling Company and got them to send a steamboat and barge to bring in the launch. This was done with great difficulty as the boat had sunk and was badly damaged. The boat was taken to the Stone Boat Company in Kenora who built it, and on receipt of an estimate from them I will write you and get further instructions as to what should be done in the matter.

Re: Alleged Ring of Liquor to Indians at Whitefish Indian Reserve, Lake of the Woods, Ont., Indian Act.

On the behalf Capt. F. Edwards, Indian Agent at Kenora, Ont., informed me that he had received information to the effect that liquor was being run to the Indians at Whitefish Reserve and requested that the matter be investigated.

On my inquiries about Kenora I learned from the Provincial Police that there was a shortage of beer in the local store and that they had been watching the Brewery Door (not night) for the past two weeks in an effort to catch some trading.

Capt. Patterson of the C.F.Police stated that he would help watch the channels going to Whitefish if a suitable boat could be had for the work, and that with such Department cooperation the chances of success would be doubled.

I explained the situation to Capt. F. Edwards and told him that the Police boat was too small for the work at this season of the year. The Captain said that he would run us up in the Indian Department's boat but it had been taken out for the year. However, he said that he would arrange to get the Indian school boat for the trip if we could get a mechanic. This we did.

On the 12th Inst. I left in the Indian School Boat for Whitefish district with Capt. Patterson of the C.F.Police and R. Moore, Mechanic. We watched the channels going to Whitefish until the afternoon of the 14th Inst. without seeing any boats going to Whitefish with the exception of the Keewatin Lumber Co.'s Tug. There were several boats came up as far as Yellow Girl and nearby islands but none went towards Whitefish.

On the afternoon of the 14th Inst. when returning to Kenora and about eight miles out the clutch slipped and would not drive the boat, when it was tightened by the Mechanic it would stop the engine when it was put in gear. The Mechanic stated that nothing could be done as the Clutch was worn out.

There was a big sea running at the time so we got the Anchor out but owing to the shortness of the Anchor rope it was unable to hold the boat in the sea that was running with the result that we were blown ashore on the North shore of Quay Island the boat was damaged and filled with water.

On the following day we reached Kenora in another boat and I reported to Captain F. Edwards what happened. He requested me to go with the Tug and show the Captain where the boat was. I left with the Tug on the same day and had the boat at J.V. Stone's (Boat Company) dry dock at about 10 am on the 16th Inst.

You can make better arrangements by purchasing on the cash basis. In other cases, of course, you should forward a properly certified account, in duplicate, in favour of those from whom the stock is purchased. The Department will then send official cheques direct to the vendors. It is understood that the Canadian Breeder's Association will assist you in making the selection, that you will purchase grade animals in the main and that no unnecessary expense will be incurred. It is considered that not more than 10 milkers, 10 heifers and one bull should be secured. If fewer animals will satisfy the needs of the school, the Department will be grateful if you will curtail the expenditure. I do not consider it necessary for a department representative to be with you when making the selection. The matter will be left in your hands.

Dear Sir:

We have just completed a test of our herd for T.B. The test being made by the Government Veterinary Surgeon from Dryden, Ontario. In regard to one cow Minnie's Queen -22653L- This cow was bought one year ago from D. Z. Gibson of Oakwood, Ontario being bought under test. None of the herd here showed a reaction with the exception of this one cow. She showed a reaction. This cow was our finest one in the herd and I was counting on her for a foundation cow. She was in splendid condition and a good feeder, and outside the test there were no indications whatever to lead one to suspect her. She was a very valuable animal with a good record behind her. I suggested to the Vet. that I remove her immediately from the premises and have her placed under quarantine in order that I might save the calf. He insisted that we destroy her and we had her killed. The Vet. was present when she was killed and he removed every gland and every organ and examined them very carefully and could not find any indication whatsoever of the disease being present. I consider the Vet. did what he considered was his duty, but I sincerely think that something else other than T.B. produced the reaction. I don't believe the animal had the disease, and the Butcher emphatically declares he could see nothing to indicate the least symptoms of the disease.

We have sustained a very severe loss in having to destroy this animal, and I feel that we should be recompensed from some source. It seems to me that it was a very drastic measure to destroy such a valuable cow upon the first test.

Dear Sir,

Re test cattle Bovine Infectious Abortion

I wish to inform you that I have received the report of the test made on our herd for the above infection. Thirty head were tested; 14 Negative, 13 Positive and 3 questionable.

All of our pure breeds went down with the exception of 3.

I would like to offer the following suggestion to your Department:

In view of the fact that B.I. Abortion is such a difficult disease to stamp out from a herd and also taking into consideration that other may develop the infection later, the further the most valuable part of our herd is involved, I would like to suggest that we ship the entire herd and dispose of them all, thus keep our supply of milk until school closes in July and not replace our herd until Sept. 1st. This would leave the premises free of stock for a period of over four months during which interval with a thorough disinfecting and the sunlight and fresh air, all infection should be well cleared up.

At least $1500 would be required to replace sufficient animals for our required milk supply which sum would have to be provided by the Dept. Any Proceeds from the disposal of the present herd would be required to pay for the milk supply during the four or five months.

Being as it is at the close of a severe winter during which feed was very scarce and also high in price the cattle are not in a salable condition and will not realise much.

I consider it very unwise to retain any of the herd when once the infection has set in and a few months without stock would make it much more safe of any further infection.

The summer vacation being only a few months ahead will work in very well with the plan I have suggested.

I shall await further instructions.

I remain

The cow barn has been whitewashed and cleaned but I found in them two head of cattle, a cow and heifer, which had been purchased to butcher. I objected to bringing in these cattle because this might lead to defeat the object of having a clean germ-free stable for some teatred cattle. I asked concerning the proposed herd and Mr. Byers stated he had partly arranged to get four Ayrshire heifers from a man near Teulon, Manitoba. The school needs milk cows not heifers and I would recommend that six or eight cows be purchased and these should be kept fresh or put to freshen. If we are planning to get milk for this winter we hardly see the use of buying cows before spring. If and when the cows are to be purchased, would it not be advisable to secure the services of a veterinary from the Health of Animals Branch here. I am informed they are willing to co-operate in any work of this nature. You will also point out that Mr. Byers has a good short horn bull which he purchased last spring at the Brandon Bull sale. I advised him at the time to wait for the result of the Bank's test in his herd; but he was determined to buy the bull, and did. I think it is a mistake to jump from one breed to another and we all must admit that the short horn cattle are hard to beat, for an all around general purpose breed. On the other hand, if he is only desirous of milk then either Holstein or Ayrshire should be selected.
EX'D.

SPLENDID BOAT FOR INDIAN DEPARTMENT.

An Ideal Servicable Craft being built by the J. W. Stone Boat Manufacturing Co. - Other boats constructed or under construction - A busy place.

While manufacturing plants all over the continent have been more or less beating time during the past few months due to the uncertainty of the demand for their products, the J. W. Stone Boat Manfg. Co. have been going ahead all winter as if there were no dull times. They have constructed a large number of skiffs for stock and also several large and attractive launches, for which they hope to secure a ready sale during the coming season.

Splendid Boat for Indian Dept.:

Last week the company commenced the construction of a large boat for the department of Indian affairs, and already the hull is in shape and giving evidence of its splendid lines. The contract was secured by them some weeks ago in open tender with large eastern boat building firms. The plans and specifications had been originally approved by Capt. F. Edwards, Indian agent for this district and he was particularly pleased that a local firm secured the contract.

The boat is 40 feet long with a beam of 8 feet 8 inches, is of the full cabin type. It will be equipped with comfortable sleeping accommodations for six persons with two bunks in the forward end and four in the after cabin. Those in the rear cabin will go up to the walls after the style of those in the standard sleeping car coaches and when not in use will only take up about five inches of space on each side. Every possible convenience in a boat of this size will be provided, including lavatory, pantry, etc. It will also be fitted with electric lights.

The motive power will be provided by a four cylinder Campbell, rated at from 29 to 40 h.p., equipped with electric starter, complete with all the latest improvements. Mr. Stone is proud of the model and the material going into the construction of the boat is perfect. Speaking to the Mining and News representative yesterday, Mr. Stone said it was his ideal of a boat and apparently he is determined to produce a boat satisfactory to himself and his customers and one particularly adapted to navigation of the Lake of the Woods.

In addition to the comfort and general utility of the boat, it will be capable of carrying large quantities of supplies, which is sometimes necessary in the work carried on by the Indian agent. The cost of the boat will be from $4,500 to $5,000.

The engine is under a bridge deck to which all controls are led, leaving a very roomy cockpit aft for passengers or freight. We were also obliged to engage an engineer to give the engine an overhauling as we could not work the clutch which had been damaged and one of the Tappet rods was stripped. The engineer's time cost us over $60.

The total expense incurred should not be any charge against the school as we sent the boat out in good condition and it was not in as good a condition after the above work had been done on it.

I shall appreciate it if you will explain this to the Department.

I remain, Sir,

METHOD OF DISINFECTION

(TUBERCULOSIS)

1. Remove manure completely from floor and walls by thorough scraping.

2. Sweep carefully all corners, crevices and positions where dust may collect around sills, plates and roof timbers, and remove dust, screenings, cobwebs, and other refuse.

3. Sweep out thoroughly mangers, feed-racks and troughs, runways and passages and scrub thoroughly with hot water and lye.

4. Burn all scrapings and sweepings.

5. Empty and scrub individual drinking bowls or drinking troughs with approved disinfectant solution.

6. Apply heavy even coating of approved disinfectant solution mixed with linewash to floors, walls, partitions, mangers, feed-racks and gutters. Advice as to proportions of mixture can be had from the veterinary inspectors.

7. Remove all manure, straw, bedding, and other refuse from neighbourhood of barn.

Dear Sir:

With reference to Departmental letter of September 9, File 129-8-16, re purchase of cattle for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, I wish to state that I have travelled over a large amount of territory in the hope of locating suitable cows, but without success.

I have interviewed farmers throughout the Carman, Morden, Portage la Prairie, and Brandon districts. The only cows I could purchase were the culled. A farmer with a good cow would not part with it. This is due largely to the fact that there is no sale market and farmers hope to make their living from dairy products. Good milk cows have gone up in price. Mr. Wilson, of Roland, told me he sold a dairy cow last week at a sale in the stockyards here for $112.00, and I believe this is about the price that is now being asked for good milk cows.

On my return today I interviewed Mr. Diamond, of Diamond & Kars, to see if he had any suitable cows. I was greatly impressed with some 8 or 10 which he now has on hand, from which I can make a selection. These will cost in the neighborhood of $90.00 per head, tested both for tuberculosis and Bang's disease. Mr. Diamond is selling cows every day; therefore these may be gone at any time.

I am positive it will be difficult and expensive to continue searching throughout the country for 6 or 7 cows, and would therefore request authority by wire to make the purchase from Mr. Diamond. INTRADERMIC CODE

A. Animals showing no reaction shall be recorded at each observation as N (negative).

B. Reactions shall be recorded as follows:

a. For circumscribed swellings, pea size (diameter 8-16 inch) shall be used as the basic standard. Larger swellings shall be recorded as P3, P5, P7, etc.

b. For diffused swellings, Thick 2x shall be used as the basic standard and signifies a diffuse swelling in which the injected caudal fold is twice as thick as the normal fold. Larger swellings shall be recorded as Thick 3x, Thick 4x, etc.

OPHTHALMIC CODE

Key L = Lacrimation.

½ X = Very slight or trace of discharge.

¼ X = Slight discharge, which may have a characteristic appearance or not.

Practice and experience alone will guide the operator what classification should be made of ½ x or ¼ x. The character of exudate should be carefully considered, also the time and duration of discharge. A good characteristic reaction should come up quickly and continue for a period of several hours at least. In some cases a reaction may be noted without lacrimation. These reactions are not very strong as a rule, probably x or xx, and are termed as dry reactions and in most cases reveal lesions on autopsy.

Memorandum of an Inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of
Alvin Oshie ..........................................., Pupil No. 232
of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School at Kenora,
who died at the above school ........ (place) on April, 20th, 1938.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry,
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical
Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's
presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's
death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be
permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The Inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Sir,

Re Alvin Osbie

The above named boy was left at the school by the mother without instructions from her.

The boy's father is dead and the mother has remarried. The step-father refuses to have anything to do with the above boy and the school has given him shelter and food and clothing for over a year.

We have not entered his name on the register previous to this quarter, the Church having assumed the expense of caring for him.

We have had a new teacher take charge of the room in which this boy was and she entered his name with the others taking it for granted he was a regularly enrolled pupil.

This boy has never been very strong physically and he contracted whooping-cough, then tonsillitis then basal pharyngitis and passed away during the night of the twentieth of present month. The Church provided him also a grave and in so doing avoided his being sent to hospital in which case there would have been considerable expense placed on the Department.

I am sorry his name appeared on the last quarterly return but I have never been able to comprehend why he was never allowed to be admitted as a pupil. His mother is a member of our Church, his father was Anglican, and as for his age we have had pupils just as young as he.

Had we turned him out of the school I do not think he would have found a welcome anywhere. In view of the circumstances death may have been kind to him. We were very sorry to see him pass away.

I remain,

Hon. Sir,

Having learned that there is a possibility of the work in connection with the Indian School here being abandoned on account of the difficulties in the way of financing the project, and knowing the local circumstances as we do and the great need of work of this character being carried on in order to prevent the utter demoralization of the Indians and through them to a large extent the white men coming in contact with them, we the undersigned Residents of Chapleau and surrounding district humbly appeal to you and through you to the Government to come to the assistance of this school with such financial aid as will make its future maintenance and development a certainty, and we would ask the liberty of pointing out the following reasons why we feel that this work should be undertaken by the Indian Department.

I have not been able to communicate with Principal Mr. Thornton, as there was no opportunity, but I know that the conditions are much similar here as they are not only the increased cost of foodstuffs and other supplies to be met, but the increased cost of transportation.

I will give you just one item as an example, in which I enclose the freight charges.

I purchased from the Selvie Flour Mills Co. at Montreal in May 1917 an entire supply of 25 bags of second grade flour (Stone Baking), paying $157.50 for it and $3.95 insurance. The transportation charges to Charlton were $83.42 and from Charlton to Moore @ $6 per ton = $10.50 additional.

Thus by the time the flour reached Moore, not counting the handling charges, there we paid $171.87 for transportation or $755.37, nearly 1/3 more than the original cost.

To bring all these charges into account, I conclude that a reasonable per capita grant which would cover about half the cost of maintenance in each school, would be an increase of $25 on the present grant, $115 for the Chaplain School and $150 for the Moore School.

Dear Mr. Scott,

The Honorable Archibald Matheson has requested me to send you a statement as to our need for an increase in the per capita grant for our Indian Boarding Schools.

He mentioned that living everywhere in Canada is well known to you. It is needless for me to say that this fact is most keenly felt in the maintenance of our Boarding Schools where we have been having a very hard struggle to make ends meet, especially during the last four years and the struggle is becoming harder all the time. The increase of $10 per capita granted by the Department in 1916 was a matter promised but still wholly inadequate to meet the continually rising expenditure.

After receiving his Private's letter I wrote to Principal Palmer of our Chaplain School asking him to give me the approximate annual cost of maintenance paid by the per capita grant of last year. His reply is that "the Department paid us about $250 less than was promised, i.e., about one third of the cost of maintenance."
A bill in action and we died in England some time before a tax revision. This is an additional reason why we should do what we can for them and provide the best possible educational advantages under the most favorable conditions of living.

I wrote in some time ago regarding the pressing necessity of an increase in the per capita grants. The financial situation especially at Chaplean is serious. The principal in his report to me states that "the grants for the present year at the old rate of $90 will just about meet one-fourth of our present year's expenditure." The cost of living in Chaplean is very high due to the fact that its town is so far removed from producing centres and at the mercy of the one railway. Without an ear to them because they can purchase in Canada but not enjoy the advantage of a fair margin, which we cannot do. Purchasing locally is very high and the freight or outside purchases is necessary limited quantities is almost prohibitive.

I trust therefore that the Department will give our case a fair and sympathetic consideration and decide to give us at least the per capita grant I asked for in my former communication, which is not unreasonable in view of the very hard times through which we are passing. The increase will be all the more necessary for the needs of the new school if we are to do satisfactory and successful work.

With many thanks for past consideration and kindness,

Dear Sir,

I am writing to express my concern about the building of the new school at Chapleau. I believe there will be no delay and that the school will be erected at once. It is almost unnecessary for me to mention how entirely unsuitable the present building is for successful work as you are well aware of the facts. Not only is the present building obsolete, but the need of increased accommodation is urgent. The epidemic of influenza has caused many deaths among our Indians and left many orphans whom we have to care for. We must act quickly and with whom we can do the best work.

The opportunity of obtaining land with whom we can do the best work is rare. The principal, Mr. Smith, has been in charge of the school for several years and has done an excellent job. He cannot accept as the school is now filled to the limits of its capacity. There are already 50 pupils ready for the new school. Now is the time for action and I do hope that the Department will take steps to proceed immediately with the building and acquire a suitable site which has been thoroughly investigated for good reasons.

We are proud of our Indians at the Chapleau Agency, and desire their connection with the local community. We believe that they are a valuable part of the community and should be treated with respect.

OTTAWA, June 14th, 1921.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant regarding the summer holidays allowed the Chapleau Boarding School.

In reply, I beg to say that under the agreement for the maintenance and management of Indian Boarding Schools, one month's pay during the holidays is allowed with grant. This is the policy followed with grant to all Indian Residential Schools, and the Department is not prepared to make any exception in the case of the Chapleau Boarding School.

With reference to allowing the pupils to go home during the period granted as summer holidays, this is optional on the part of the Principal. In all cases where he is reasonably sure that the pupil will be promptly returned upon the expiry of their leave, he may grant them permission to spend the holidays at home. In cases where there has been trouble in the past in having the parents return their children, the question of again allowing such children permission to go home should be carefully considered. Where the Principal is justified in doubt that a child will not be returned, he should not allow him leave of absence, and in all cases where leave is granted, the Principal should obtain written agreement from the parent or guardian that the child will be returned promptly upon the expiry of leave.

As you are on the ground and have a better view of the situation, you may use your own discretion as to which pupils you allow to go home. At the end of the holidays, if any child fail to return, you know I immediately write to the Agent of the Band to which they belong and he should take the necessary steps to have them promptly returned to the school.

The Department has no form or permit which a parent or guardian can sign agreeing to return a child upon the expiry of the annual leave.

It is noted that you have a number of new pupils in view when the school re-opens, and it is hoped that you will be successful in obtaining the full number for whom the grant is allowed.

The attached petition from some Indians resident at Franz, Ont., asking for the dismissal of Mr. Preror as Principal of the boarding school at Chapleau, Ont., was handed in personally by Mr. Henry Jackson, President of the Grand Indian Council, last week.

While I do not think that it is necessary to formally investigate the management of the school, I do think that a visit from the Superintendent of Indian Education at a convenient time would be in the interest of all concerned. We all know Mr. Preror has worked on his work here for years under extreme difficulties, and I think that a visit from the officer above referred to would be stimulating and encouraging to him.

If you agree, I would suggest that Mr. Jackson be advised that an inspection of this school will be made by Mr. Ferrier some time after the New Year. I am mentioning this date on Mr. Jackson's suggestion, as he says the Indians will all be on their reserves about that time.

Charles Fletcher did not freeze his toes delivering milk in Chapleau town, for, in a personal "chummy" chat with this boy, I found that only once had his feet been cold. Indeed, he had come to the school, and that was when he, in company with a lot of other boys, had gone some 300 yards from the school to watch a team that was floundering in the snow and to assist in shoring the load back onto the hard road.

Concerning the cut on his knee, the affidavit mentions this winter, whereas it was a year ago that the boy's knee was sore. The boy says—it was not particularly sore—but that he did not do any work before Christmas 1920; that Miss Turner (an officer) attended to it regularly.

The affidavit mentions that Charles and Carrie Fletcher had been at the school for four years; but, after an examination of the register, I find that they have been there but two and a half years.

Andrew Saunders says when he came back three weeks before, to take his children James (II) and Jessie (II), home for the holidays, he found both of them, lousy and dirty. Alice Neigan took her children, M. and T., years of age, to the school in July, 1921. They both had the lice immediately, but it is now healing up. Kitty Sahakoteway says she was quite well when she went to the school but took scurfula there. The Doctor said her skin got it from some other girl. They all used the same towels. These are simply isolated cases. The complaint over the whole school can be imagined. Harry Black says the whole school is "full" of itch.

Margaret Nolan says her son David has not received the clothes she bought him. Caroline Shequian says the same thing about her son Willie. Margaret Gideon says the Principal took the boots she had bought for her daughter Beatrice and made her go barefoot. She found her son Jack working in the bush and the clothes supplied him gone. Isaiah Dick says his children did not receive the clothing purchased by him for them. Alice Neigan makes a similar complaint regarding clothing of her children. I was informed verbally by the witness Harry Black that many of these children, girls as well as boys, are without underclothes, even at this season and in such a climate.

Isaiah Dick says his two girls have been pupils at the school since September, 1921, but cannot say whether speak or understand English or know their alphabet. Beatrice Fletcher says her son, Charles aged 12, has been at the school four years and is now in the second reader and can read or write very little. Sir:

Instructions were recently received by me from certain Indians, the parents of children attending the Chapleau Indian Boarding School to present complaints on their behalf against the administration of Mr. George Brewer, principal of said school. On the 16th and 17th January, 1922, I was at Chapleau for the purpose of receiving the statements of these people, which took the form of statutory declarations made by the several parties.

I might say before discussing these complaints, that at my request the number of Indians in attendance was ascertained and found to be fifty-one only of whom had come a less distance than thirty miles, and some as far as 150 miles, to attend the charges. When one considers the inclemency of the weather and the great expense these people were met, it could not be said they were very much in earnest in their desire to better the condition of affairs at present prevailing in this school.
