To sum up my findings in connection with the specific charges in the affidavits presented by Mr. Chisholm, I wish to state that in every case the truth has been distorted and the testimony is largely false. It is the opinion of Mr. Agent Godfrey and Mr. McLeod of Chapleau, who was once an Indian agent and has the interests of the Indians at heart, that some of the Indians did not know what they were claiming and were not aware of the nature of the statutory declaration. I myself find that Mr. Agent Godfrey informed me that Henry Jackson asked the Indians at the time of the petition to swear to the charges they were making, and they refused.

The information which I gleaned concerning the individual charges mentioned in the affidavits has been placed on file in the form of notes attached to the individual declarations.

I believe I can throw light on these ridiculous charges that have been brought against the Rev. George Prewer, Principal of the Chapleau Boarding school. The initial agitation was caused by one Jacob Candaasee. This man was a Church of England native catechist and was relieved of his duties by the Rev. Mr. Prewer a few months ago for misappropriation of church funds.

Secondly, the Fletcher and Blacks of the Frans area are related to the Indian Candaasee, and appear to be at present the leaders of the agitation. It was Fletcher who collected the $325 in fees for Mr. Chisholm of Ontario, Ont., whereas Fletcher and Black have a personal grudge against the Rev. Mr. Prewer because he was so unsuccessful in literally forcing their way into the Chapleau school on June 30th last. Mr. Fletcher, on this occasion, actually had to defend himself from the assault of these two women in conjunction with Mrs. Chequain. (This last named Indian woman signed one of the affidavits.) This second explanation of the charges in the petition could be enlarged upon by showing that there is in the Indian community a dislike for the Rev. Mr. Prewer, due to his harsh-handed treatment of parents and others. The white citizens of Chapleau and other centres, in many cases are slow to take Mr. Prewer's side, due to his close-fisted business activities.

Thirdly, the storm centre is at Frans. Thirteen of the sixteen affidavits conclude with the statement that the parent wishes the child to be discharged from the Chapleau Indian Industrial School for the purpose of attending the public school, and nine of these declarations specifically mention the public school at Frans. The petition of last September was signed in Frans at the office of Mr. J. Belair, who, I understand, is on the trustees' board of the public school. The white community needs the support of the Indian families to make their school a success, and they are asking the Indians to have their children released for this manifest purpose. Underlying their action is their need for financial support; in fact, from the standpoint of the Indians, the court is before the horde. Mr. Godfrey's authority for stating that nearly $1,000 has already been paid by Indians of the Frans area to the support of the white school there.
AFFILIATION OF CHILD LABOUR: I have been at many schools where our Indian wards work longer hours and heavier work than at the Chapleau Boarding School. The boys' hands present no evidence that they are or have been, overworked. The regular school hours, for the boys who are old enough to be of age, are 7:30 to 9:45 and 5:30 to 6, a total of 8 hours and 45 minutes per day. The boys who look after the horses and stock put in an extra half hour in the morning and at night, but these boys receive in payment of their extra service pocket money to the extent of 25 cents per day. The pupils last mentioned are in charge of the teams, do the milking and deliver milk to the town.

In the affidavits referred to "paddling of milk and wood" received frequent mention. The Reverend Mr. Inver makes all sales of milk and the boys (2) who deliver it have a regular route. They are well clothed, receive 25 cents per day for their extra work and clock at the school at 10 a.m. in time for the classroom instruction. The milk was supplied in the first instance at the request of Dr. Sheahan and others of Chapleau, because of the uncertain quality of the milk that had been supplied to the residents. As far as the wood-cutting operations are concerned, I ascertained that outsiders contributed to cut the wood and the boys in charge of the teams hauled and delivered it to residents in the town. Wood and milk have never been "paddled". Orders have been, in every case, taken by the Principal himself. Last winter some 300 cords of wood was sold in the town and the boys who drove the teams got One Dollar for their bank accounts when on this kind of work. Information concerning the sale of wood and milk was gleaned from the Principal himself, Mr. Godfrey and the boys who are at present in charge of the teams and the milk supply.

CLOTHING: I am convinced that every child in the school has heavy under-clothing, in addition to adequate outerwear and footwear.

MEDICINE: I enquired carefully into the cases of neglect mentioned in the affidavits, and, while I found that the principal has been somewhat slow to call in medical attention, he himself, because of his experience, is fairly well qualified to look after minor ailments; and I might say that the charges in this connection have been so greatly exaggerated that they are misrepresentations of the facts.

CRUELTY: The discipline of the Principal is severe; but not one pupil corroborated the statements made in this connection in the affidavits. The second day of my visit, after having played with the boys and I believe won their confidence, I questioned each boy in private (with the knowledge of the Principal) and find that the affidavits are nothing short of a tissue of lies.

Mr. Scott:

I have the honour to report on my recent visit to the Chapleau Boarding School.

On Tuesday, the 17th, the department received here 16 affidavits and a covering letter from Mr. A. G. Chisholm, of London, Ont., all of which referred to the improper management of the Rev. Mr. Freer, Principal of the Chapleau Boarding School. You asked me to leave that same night for Chapleau, for the purpose of an official inspection. Previous to this, the Department had received from Henry Jackson, President of the Grand Indian Council, a petition, signed by certain Indians of the Chapleau and Frans districts, in which they asked for the removal of the Rev. Mr. Freer.

In view of the nature of some of the charges brought against the Rev. Mr. Freer, I thought it advisable to "walk in on the school" unannounced. I wished to check up: (1) the clothing in use; (2) the cleanliness of the pupils; (3) the condition of the school; (4) the hours of instruction; before any change could be made in the routine of the school. Later, I endeavoured to inquire into: (5) the care of the sick; (6) the progress of the pupils' studies; (7) the nature of the work done by the children, with particular reference to the sale of milk and wood.

Ten minutes after entering the front door, I saw 95 of the 98 pupils and was in a position to know something of the daily routine. I had not been in the building one-half hour before I had examined four boys and two girls, with a view to ascertaining the nature of the clothing provided, the cleanliness of the pupils, and the presence, or absence, of body and head vermin.

I hold the following convictions concerning the charges made in the petition and affidavits that came to hand:

FILTHY CONDITION: The children are fairly clean; head lice are practically nil; no body lice were found and there is but a minimum of skin disease (eczema and scabies).

LACK OF ACADEMIC INSTRUCTION: 85 junior pupils are receiving daily 4 hours of classroom teaching and 39 senior pupils 5 hours per day. 4 older boys in charge of the teams receive somewhat less classroom instruction, but they are paid for their extra work. These 4 boys spend alternate days at work and in the classroom.
A report on the Chapleau Indian Boarding School is not complete without a special report on the Principal. The Rev. Mr. Brewer has devoted his life to Indian work. He is proud of the Chapleau Indian Boarding School and his ability to finance without outside help. He drives a hard business deal, pays no interference and deals with all school matters in an altogether autocratic manner. His methods make him disliked in the community and inflict upon himself an ever-lasting stigma. The effect on the pupils is two-fold: they have to work faithfully and endure a severe discipline. I have suggested to the Principal that it may be necessary for him to have the M.B.C.C. or the Board of Education's deficit if the Chapleau Indian Boarding School is to present a pleasing picture to the white community, the Indian parents and the pupils themselves. The man's personal appearance is not prepossessing; in addition, he is a cripple; he believes the world to be against him and glories in it.

I made the following requests and suggestions to the Rev. Mr. Brewer: (1) More careful attention to the cleanliness of the building; (2) more thoughtful consideration of the feelings of the staff; (3) the thoughtful and earnest avoidance of any treatment of the pupils that could be considered by outsiders as pitiless; (4) an immediate cessation of any work bordering on the nature of the exploitation of child labour; (5) a consistent reference to the Medical Officer in cases of injury or illness. I promised a definite understanding with Dr. Sheahan, the Medical Officer.

I informed the Principal of the nature of my report and advised him that I would make an effort to have both the M.B.C.C. and the Department of Indian Affairs come to his assistance, so that the unpleasant features that have given rise to the local adverse criticism could be eliminated.

Generally speaking, the Chapleau Indian Boarding School is doing splendid work for our Indian wards. The cause would receive a severe setback if the services of the Rev. Mr. Brewer were lost.

[Signature]

Superintendent of Indian Education.
OTHER INSTRUCTION: The teaching activities in the Chapleau Boarding School are largely confined to academic instruction in the classroom. A more efficient staff and a better time-table will have to be provided to permit of an all round training. I will make a suggestion concerning these matters in the form of a brief memorandum.

CONDITION OF THE BUILDING: A new building should be practically spotless, and I have to report that the Chapleau Boarding School is only fairly clean. The boys' side is more at fault than any other portion of the institution. I wish to draw your attention, in my memorandum, to one alteration and one repair that I believe to be necessary.

FARM: The Chapleau Indian Boarding school is severely handicapped financially, because of the nature of the property. I cannot foresee that the farming operations will ever be a source of revenue. Secondly, the pasture facilities are poor, and it will be some years before the farm at Chapleau will be an asset. The majority of Indian residential schools, as you know, find their farming activities a source of revenue.

DAILY ROUTINE: At all seasons of the year the following time-table is adhered to rigidly:

5:30 a.m. Reveille - milking and the care of stock, preparation of breakfast.
6:30 a.m. Breakfast and prayers.
7:00 a.m. Chores, cleaning and other work.
9:45 a.m. Preparation for school.
10 a.m. School - every pupil except the two boys with the teams, in attendance.
12 a.m. Lunch.
12:30 Recreation.
1:30 p.m. School.
3:00 p.m. Lunch.
4:00 p.m. Recreation.
6:00 p.m. Supper and Evening prayers.
7:00 p.m. Younger children retire - Senior classroom instruction.
8:00 p.m. Senior pupils retire.

I criticised this time-table, especially for the winter months, and informed the Principal that we would have instructions for him in this connection. My recommendation will be presented in the form of a memorandum.

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

I wish to offer my report on the Chapleau Indian Boarding School:

STAFF: This institution is a "one man" school. The Rev. George Brewer is Principal and his wife Matron. There are 7 others on the staff, only 3 of which can properly be called teachers or officers: Miss Thomas, Senior Teacher, well qualified and of excellent spirit - Miss McCauley Junior Teacher and Girls' Matron and Miss Tracey, Boys' Matron, the last two also splendidly equipped for their work. I consider Mrs. Brewer an excellent officer, without whom the institution would have been decidedly unpopular; she has a tempering and beneficial influence upon the Principal, her husband. The four other members of the staff are nothing more than hired help - three women who are in the kitchen, laundry and dairy and the man who does all of the work. Rev. Mr. Brewer is not negligible although somewhat crippled, he supervises every detail of the school activities and is quite often found at hard manual labour himself. The accommodation for the staff is very limited, and in the future we shall have to provide a principal's residence. There is a real and immediate need for a strong assistant who can eventually take over the principalship. Such a man could take off the shoulders of Dr. Brewer the burden of details and enable him to concern himself with general administration. The Rev. Mr. Brewer would leave the Indian work if he felt the institution that he has fostered for the past ten years would be a continued success. I understand that he has private means which, it is only fair to state, have to the best enabled him to keep the school in excellent condition. The hired help on the staff should be replaced by officers who can give instruction in domestic training and farming and gardening operations.

CLASSROOM: The two teachers now in the school are specially fitted for Indian work in addition to being professionally qualified. The instruction in English, and generally has been in the past but fair. On the other hand, the reasoning faculty of the older pupils shows a careful training in Arithmetic that compares favourably with the best students in most of our residential schools in the Prairie Provinces. Both rooms are very crowded and I suggested to the Principal a different daily routine which will enable him to place one teacher in each room in the classroom at a time. In the Junior room there were 50 boys and girls and in the Senior room 35 the morning I made my census of the pupils. This is too many for successful teaching. In both rooms I made an effort to offer pedagogical methods that I believe are efficient in an Indian classroom.
(b) To rearrange the time-table and the daily routine of his school for at least five winter months, the hour of rising to be 6.30 a.m. instead of 5.30 and the routine known as the "half day system" be initiated.

(c) To immediately cease such activities as the sale of milk and wood and arrange to give the older girls and boys more instruction in domestic training and gardening and farming, respectively.

(d) To give careful and thoughtful attention to the discipline problem of his school and to assiduously avoid any treatment that could be considered by outsiders as pitiless.

(e) To call upon the services of the medical officer without hesitation, in case of injury or sickness.

With a view to bettering conditions at the Chapleau Boarding School, I wish to suggest that the Department take the following action to assist the Rev. Mr. Prewer in his work. I am convinced that the activities which have made the school unpopular with certain groups can be curtailed if the Department and the Diocesan authorities commit to relieving the Principal of his financial burdens. Further, Mr. Prewer's untiring energy will be released for more truly educational work and for the general administration of the school.

My recommendations are as follows:

1. That the Department place the Chapleau Boarding School in the Western group, in order that the per capita grant will be raised to $120. In this category, along with first class buildings, owned by the Government, Western group, we have at present only one Ontario Boarding school, that at Fort Frances.

2. That the Department inform Bishop Anderson of the requests that we are making to the Rev. Mr. Prewer. These instructions will make it more difficult for him to finance his school, because he will have to eliminate any activity that might be considered exploitation of child labour. We could explain to the Bishop that we are helping the school financially, by changing its category, and we could ask the Church to give some financial assistance in the event of a deficit from year to year.

3. That the Diocesan authorities be approached, with a view to having them place an able assistant principal at the Chapleau Boarding school. Such a man could relieve the present principal of some of his most onerous duties and would also be a check on conduct and management that has in the past made the institution unpopular. I might state that the Rev. Mr. Prewer would welcome such an appointment to his staff.

4. That the Department instruct the Rev. Mr. Prewer:
   (a) To get rid of his "hired help" and employ officers who can be of truly educational assistance.

Dear Canon Gould:

The Department is requesting the Rev. Mr. Frewer, Principal of the Chapleau Indian Boarding School, to curtail certain activities which, I believe, are the underlying reasons for the unpopularity of this institution with a clique of Indian people of the Frank area. Further, we are asking the Diocesan authorities to augment the staff of the school.

These requests will make it more difficult for the Principal to finance, and I have to inform you that the Department has changed the category of the Chapleau Boarding School: It has been placed in a class known as "First class building owned by the Government, Western Group." This allows for an increase of $50.00 in the per capita grant.

Bishop Anderson has been written concerning these matters and his sympathy and assistance have been enlisted.

The advisability of the M.A.C.C., having an oversight over the Chapleau Boarding School impresses me more and more, as I review the facts that have lately come to our attention. Again, as you know, the Department of Indian Affairs eagerly awaits the time when each religious denomination will have an organization with an oversight over all the Indian work in Canada that comes under its care.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.B.,
General Secretary,

Rev. Reverend Sir:

I have to inform Your Lordship that during the past few months complaints have been brought to the attention of the Department concerning the conduct of the Chapleau Indian Boarding School under the principalship of the Rev. George Fraser. These complaints were largely directed against the principal himself and his administration, and during the past month became of such a serious nature that the Department saw fit to investigate.

The Superintendent of Indian Education spent several days at the Chapleau Boarding School and in the vicinity, and I am pleased to inform you that conditions are much better than had been reported; yet, there are certain changes and improvements that must be made, if the cause among our Indian wards at Chapleau is to prosper.

The following instructions are being given to the Rev. Mr. Fraser:

1. That he get rid of certain "hired help" and employ officers who can be of value in educating Indian children.

2. That he rearrange the time-table and daily routine of the school for at least five of the winter months - the hour of rising to be 6.30 instead of 5.30 a.m.; we are also advising an initiation of the "half day" system for these months.

3. That he immediately cease such activities as the sale of milk and goods, and arrange to give the older girls and boys more instruction in domestic training and gardening and farming, respectively.

4. That he give careful and thoughtful attention to the discipline problem of the school and assiduously avoid any corporal punishment that could be considered by outsiders as pitiless.

5. That he call upon the services of the Medical Officer without hesitation in case of injury or sickness. (The Department is endeavouring to make a more definite and satisfactory arrangement with Dr. Maclean of Chapleau).
Ottawa, February 8, 1922.

Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that during the past few months complaints have been brought to the attention of the Department concerning the conduct of the Chapleau Indian Boarding School under your principalship. These complaints were largely directed against you, personally, and concerning your administration. During the past month they became of such a serious nature that the Department saw fit to have an inspection.

Mr. Ferrier, the Superintendent of Indian Education, has made his report, and I am pleased to inform you that conditions are much better than we had been led to believe. However, there are certain changes and improvements that must be made, if the cause among our Indian wards at Chapleau is to prosper.

Therefore, the Department of Indian Affairs requests your careful attention to the following instructions:

1. Get rid of certain "hired help" and employ officers who can be of value in educating Indian children.

2. Rearrange the time-table and daily routine of the school for at least five of the winter months - the hour of rising to be 6:30 instead of 6:00 a.m.; we also advise an initiation of the "half day" system for these months.

3. Immediately cease such activities as the sale of milk and wood, and arrange to give the older girls and boys more instruction in domestic training and gardening and farming, respectively.

4. Give careful and thoughtful attention to the discipline problem of the school and assiduously avoid any corporal punishment that could be considered by outsiders as pitiless.

5. Call upon the services of the Medical Officer, without hesitation, in case of injury or sickness. (The Department is endeavouring to make a more definite and satisfactory arrangement with Dr. Sheehan of Chapleau).
I am convinced that an able assistant principal should be appointed to the Chapleau Boarding School. Such a man would:

(a) Relieve you of some of your most arduous duties,

(b) Release some of your untiring energy for more truly educational work and for the general administration of the school,

(c) Eventually be in a position to take over the principleship of one of our residential schools.

Mr. Perrier assures me that you welcome such an appointment. To take care, I have communicated with the Rt. Rev. J. G. Anderson, D.D., Bishop of Moose Cree, enlisting his aid in this connection.

The appointment of a strong assistant principal and our instructions will make it more difficult for you to finance. Therefore, the Department of Indian Affairs has changed the category of the school in order to increase the per capita grant by a sum of $10.00. From the beginning of the new fiscal year (April 1, 1928) the Chapleau Indian Boarding School will belong to the class known as "First class buildings owned by the Government, Western group". The Diocesan authorities have been asked to give some financial assistance in the event of a deficit from year to year.

I believe that, with Bishop Anderson's cooperation, and with any help this Department can give, the Chapleau Indian Boarding School will become an institution concerning which we will all be proud; and I ask your careful attention to the subject matter of this communication.

Mr. Agent Godfrey is being informed of our action.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Deacon

Dear Mr. Frewer:

I have prepared, out of my experiences when visiting residential schools, a time-table based on what is known as the "half day system." This routine has been found especially valuable in the winter months and in most schools, round the year round. There are many variations from this routine; but, as near as I can remember, it is the typical plan in use. The students of a residential school of 100 pupils are divided into three groups: A, 50 morning boys and girls; B, 35 afternoon boys and girls; C, all day students.

The older boys and girls who are of value in the departments of a school, and who should receive the benefit of domestic and farming instruction, are divided evenly into morning and afternoon groups. Roughly, 30% of the children are better off in school and at play for the entire day; they are known in my plan as group C.

6:30 a.m.: Morning.
Older boys - barns (Farmer)
Intermediate boys - wood and inside chores (Asst. principal)

Older girls - preparation of breakfast (Cook)
Intermediate girls - dormitory and household duties (3 lady officers)

7:15 a.m.: Breakfast and prayers.
8:00 a.m.: Group B to the departments (Department officers)
Groups A & C - recreation.

9:00 a.m.: Group A <school> (Senior teacher 50 pupils)
(Junior teacher 55)

12:00 a.m.: Lunch.
12:30 p.m.: Groups A, B, & C - recreation.
1:00 p.m.: Group A to the departments (Department officers)
B & C - recreation continues to 1:30.

1:30 p.m.: Groups A & C - school.
4:00 p.m.: Groups B & C - recreation.

5:00 p.m.: Group B - chores
Group C Recreation

6:00 p.m.: Supper and prayers.
7:00 p.m.: Groups A & B - school.
(The two teachers take alternate evening duty, giving instruction in general lines, (as Composition, Story-telling, debating, etc.)

7:30 p.m.: Group C retire
8:00 p.m.: Groups A & B retire.

Rev. Geo. Frewer,
Principal,
Chapleau Boarding School,
Chapleau, Ont.
Then group A or group B start their half day's work.

* Larger boys report to the farmer for duty, 3, to the assistant principal for outside chores, 4, to a lady officer for inside chores, 5 girls report to the cook for instruction and the preparation of the meals, 6 like number to the matroness and the same quota to the matron for household duties and chores.

It may be necessary to have the older boys who are caring for the stock and the girls who are preparing the breakfast rise earlier than 6:30; but this can be arranged by the two officers who are on duty in the early morning. Variations from the above plan for work in the departments will be necessary on washing and baking days; but this is a detail that can be worked out.

It may be necessary, in individual schools, to depart from this routine in a large degree, but I wish to be of help to you in any way possible and felt that you might be glad to have a routine to discuss with other principals. If I can be of assistance in any way, it will be a pleasure to respond so far as is within my power.

Letters have been directed to the Diocese and to the M.S.O.C., and better arrangements are being made with the Medical Officer, and, as I promised, I recommended a change in the category of the Chaplain boarding school.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Perrier,
supt. of Indian Education.
Dear Sir:

I have to thank you for your favour of the 2nd instant, in which you comment on various questions arising out of Mr. Perrier's visit of inspection at this institution, and for the kindness and consideration shown in dealing with the various items in connection with the recommendations made by your Department relative to the administration of affairs here.

I am certain that you appreciate fully the fact that there is nothing so absolutely perfect state of affairs, in any department of any one office, as that which the management of our Institution has been trying to bring about as close to the line as it is possible to do, with due consideration for the welfare of the work and the Indian people in general.

Schools such as this, which have practically come into being within a very short period of time, require very closely for first-time administration, orders and directions, criticism, and suggestions, and in the course of inspection, jealousies and criticisms, not only where the Indians are concerned but from the political standpoint, it is period of political upheaval, and I am congratulating ourselves that we have been able to maintain serious enough when taken as read, have been able to maintain a few, in fact, and that the persons having been in these instances, deliberately state that they do not know the contents of these declarations, and are not responsible for what was supposed to have said.

Regarding the suggestions contained in your letter, we will take a reversal policy of the school, as will realize that it will take a period of time to make any changes, and that the best thing to do would be to keep the present order, or to make a new order.

We have already acted in the matter of compensation, and have increased the salary of Mr. Jo... at a rate of $15.00 per month.

We have also acted in the matter of the dormitories, and have provided additional accommodations, there being no outside assistance, and believe that we can fully carry on the salary demands but fear that the lack of accommodation will materially interfere with our securing new personnel, and therefore, since seeing here a number of applications for positions of several capable men (name), simply because no excuse could be procured, and therefore, seeing the last applicant go by simply on the ground that there is no accommodation for himself and wife, to be.
We thank you, too, for placing this Institution in the category
...and the substantial aid this additional grant will bring in terms of food and other necessaries are gradually being realized. We could not have asked for more to finish our work. I fear that we shall still have to make less and feel of more lest financial crisis should arise, but we only handicap us in our work and add to our burdens without reflecting to the detriment of the general work of the Church. In consequence I shall have to go more into my own resources as circumstances require.

I must therefore appeal once more to you for your help before I venture upon the course which I am now taking.

Assuring you of our continued hearty cooperation in all matters, I am, etc.,

Then our barn was only roofed in temporarily and for rafters and supporting only second hand lumber. The rafters were of 2x4 material which would prove to make the length required. All under fairly well supported and broad, but roof, under the heavy weight of snow and ice, is beginning to sag, and the building requires completing in accordance with the original plan. We have only the size of the gable in width to store our hay and feed and sometimes are so crowded that it is impossible to get at what we really need.

We have improved our land to such an extent that we hope to grow ten acres of cornage, five acres of corn and five acres of another mixture, for fear that the corn might prove too tender for our climate, which however was not the case last year. This will mean that we shall need our silo and filling equipment.

Then the buildings built a year ago require paint, and there is a great deal of fencing to be done to prevent our stock straying and also for the protection of our crops. For this purpose several hundred rods of barbed wire will be needed and upwards of 1000 cedar posts, together with sharpening stones and wire stretchers.

The staff and pupils can perform all the labour connected with the fencing of the Department is satisfied to supply the posts and other material. In order to ascertain as to the cost of 1000 cedar posts, or the standard size and quality, I have already posted up notices calling upon parties to tender. Ordinarily posts have been very difficult to purchase in this locality, but there are a number of men and teams in the neighbourhood who are content to work with one or two engaged in the work of setting out wood and timber. I find that there is a probability that sufficient may be had at fairly reasonable prices. We have no cedar on our School property, and I know of none except on limited already taken. As a result we could not produce them ourselves even were we in a position to do so.

As cost of material and labour goes today I cannot see how these improvements can all be added, under a cost of less than $15,000.00 to $20,000.00. Not when we consider the permanent class of buildings the Department calls for, and such as would conform to what we already have here.

There is every likelihood of the school maintaining its rated pupilage, and it is not improbable that within a short time, the Department and the Church, working together, may see the enormous advantage and the economy, in centralizing all its educational work, to take care of all the Indian population, in this part of Northern Ontario, at this particular place, so called which, from experience, I think it well worth while working towards.

I would like the Department's opinion on the matter of the improvements suggested, and to know whether you would sanction the small expenditure mentioned for fitting up the temporary building for our farmer.

I am mailing a copy of this letter to Mr. Indian Agent Geoffrey, in case you may care to take up any of the matters referred to with him.

Very faithfully yours,

Dear Sir,

Under date, Feb 2nd, inst., I received a communication from the Deputy Superintendent General, with reference to several changes which he pointed out as being essential to the better carrying out of the work for which our present building was purposed.

Amongst these important changes, which we are bending every effort in carrying out, is the matter of employing a much larger staff.

At the present time, besides myself and Mrs. Prewer and our family of one child at home, we have seven members already on the staff, and I am expecting a young Eastern man to take the position of Farmer and Outside Superintendent at any time.

We occupy the suite of rooms on the North-East corner of the building on the first floor, which is composed of two bedrooms and a sitting-room.

If you examine the plans, you will find that there are four other staff rooms - two doubles and two singles - these are all filled, and for lack of space we have had to make use of the boy's Infirmary, and as it is so small it difficult in the case of an epidemic of any kind. As it is the school has just been experiencing a mild outbreak of chicken-pox. Four boys have had it, but they had mixed with the others most of the time we did not place them in the Infirmary.

Our Farmer-Superintendent, is to be married either early in April or May, and his wife, who is from an office in Ottawa, a young girl, would not qualify for a position at our establishment.

Besides the engagements of Mr. Franklin Scott's letter advocates the appointment of an assistant medical, and to carry out the suggestions will mean a revision of our time-table, which, if we are to take care of all the dependents as they ought to be, will mean the appointing of fully one more female worker.

This will certainly mean that we shall require a great deal more accommodation for our staff. As it is we have a great deal of difficulty in grouping our workers, in order to make their positions and temporary assignments, so as to enable them without friction to share a double room. Each worker claims they are entitled to a separate room. I think you will quite see the situation. However, it is impossible for us to comply with this. Even with the four rooms occupied by the six helpers the accommodation is far short of what is really needed.

When your Mr. Farmer was up about a month ago, I pointed all this out to him, and Mr. Indian Agent Godfrey, and would have gone into the matter but no way appeared to suggest itself except to build another house residence. One a separate building, or one attached to the old one. The latter would be more economical, as it would be less costly to build an addition to the old building than to erect a new one.

Mr. Farmer has consented to occupy the West end of the Camp, which served as a Cookery for the cook-stoves and which we did not pull down for the summer months provided we fit it up to serve as a separate building. I think could be done at a cost of not more than $100.00. This is about as much as it would cost to rent a building of this kind in Capilano for this time, and we could still use it as a Carpenter shop afterwards - the purpose to which it is being put.
Ottawa, February 27, 1882.

Sir,

In reply to Mr. Scott's letter of February 2nd relative to the Chapleau Indian Boarding School I wish to make the following report.

Taking each clause in the instructions as they appear:

1. One of the hired help referred to has already left leaving shortly after Mr. Ferrier visited the school eliminating the necessity of discharging him as he was not at all suitable for position.

2. The time table has been rearranged to conform to the instructions from the Department.

3. Steps have already been taken to discontinue the sale of milk and wood; this will take effect the first of April. The sale of wood has already been cut out but the sale of milk will be carried on to a small extent until the first of April to allow these remaining patrons to secure other service.

4. I believe more thoughtful consideration is being given in the matter of funds and supplies.

5. More attention has been given to the studies of the children since Mr. Ferrier's visit he having pointed out to the Head Principle some noticeable faults in his methods.

Generally speaking I feel the Principle is giving more of his attention and energy to the educational work and administration of the school since he decided to spend less time looking to the financial aspect of the institution, and which perhaps was being done in all good faith but to the detriment of the pupils.

The Rev. Principle is trying hard to secure a capable staff and feels that since the Department has allowed the extra increase in per capita that it is great encouragement to him to put forth every effort to make the work a success and to carry it on to the satisfaction of the Department.

Institution of a similar character as our own will be closed to either of your children, and if report is correct there is every likelihood that we may not have an opportunity of attending a public school, unless you remove from your present location.

I have gone to almost unheard of pains to secure, as teachers in our school, some of the best and most approved women the Dominion has to offer.

In the person of Miss Olive Thomas, as Senior Teacher, we secured her at a great financial sacrifice where she is concerned, taking her from a position in a City school where she was receiving a salary of $1500.00 per year, leaving with her own people in her house. I will challenge you to find, in spite of all your pretended knowledge of education and matters, her equal, as a teacher, anywhere in a school of this kind.

With the exception of some few articles of clothing, your children have been maintained free of cost to you, and they have not only been given a very fair education and taught other matters of equal importance with book learning, but their moral and religious interests have been thoroughly safe-guarded.

Practically ever since your children have been resident here both yourself and your wife, especially the latter, have sought to be little by little being made in their behalf, as also that of a number of other pupils.

The very ungrateful attitude of yourself and wife is making it not only difficult for myself to see that it is worth while doing very much more for your children, and were I to show the same disposition towards them that you have both shown, I am quite certain that their positions here would have been made very uncomfortable.

A family like your own, claiming to be leaders in missionary, especially in religious things, should be better employed than in an attempt to destroy the work of an institution of this kind, which has not only been classed as a school whose day will have an untold influence upon the younger generation of Indians of the locality, but which is destined to play an important part in the whole educational system of the Dominion.

Your feeble attempts remind me of a small boy with a pair of moccasins on kicking a huge rock, the harder he kicks the worse he suffers, and the rock remains as firm as ever.

It will be well for you both, instead of rushing on in a hasty frenzy of denunciation of our policy and plan, where your children are concerned, to stop and think whether such acts are going to do yourselves or your children any good.

I am not certain what steps the Department intends to take regarding your false declaration. I know however that it is engaging its attention at the present time.

For your future guidance however, I wish to call your attention that neither yourself or wife will be permitted to visit the school more than once a month, during the time of the residence of either of your children here, and then only through arrangements between myself and Indian Agent.

I am forwarding a copy of this letter to the Department at Ottawa and one to Mr. Indian Agent Geoffrey.

Faithfully Yours,

There are a few matters relating to this Institution affecting the conduct of yourself and wife of which I wish to write and to call your attention to.

In the first place you have two children here, Carrie and Eddie. According to the records on file with the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, these children were admitted to the school on May 15th, 1914. At the present time Carrie is in the Junior Grade and Eddie is in Grade 2. It was not until we had met your children in school that we realized how much they needed our help. Carrie has been doing very well in her studies and Eddie has been doing quite well too. We have been working hard to improve their grades and we believe that they will do even better next year.

Possibly you may not be aware of the fact that in making such a statement, the person is guilty of a very serious offense and can be prosecuted for perjury. We have heard that your two children entered the school on May 15th, 1914 according to actual calculation. It is also true that they had been here just about two years and three months when they were enrolled in the school. We have taken into consideration that during this time your child has been instructed from the Indian Department and has been enrolled in the school for moving into the new building and for dislocation during the moving period, so we say that your children are now enrolled at the school and have been there for more than two years.

In the case of Eddie, I am sure that you will find in the weeks of his residence at school in any public or private school, he would be in any manner progressing notwithstanding he is not one of the brightest of our pupils.

Your boy is not sick and has not a single blemish on him so may have been suffering from the effects of weather change. We are grateful for your cooperation and have arranged for your son to be seen by a doctor and have paid his stay in hospital. However, he is recovering and we are pleased to report that he is doing well.

In conclusion, we urge you to consider your boy's future and to make the best decision possible. We feel that it is in the best interest of your boy that he should be able to continue his education.

Dear Sir:

I wired you by night letter last night as follows: "Have eight cases of Pneumonia this. Would like you to authorize a nurse to take care of these. Staff not sufficient to continue for long period. Better supply one from Ottawa."

For the past month there has been a great deal of whooping cough amongst the smaller boys and girls, and a few cases of Chicken Pox.

The Chicken Pox had been prevalent all around in Chapleau and its points along the railway and, although we take every precaution, cases have been brought in in some way. There has been no whooping cough so far as we can gather, this season, anywhere in the neighborhood, etc., except here developed here.

With children having a tendency towards lung weakness, an epidemic of this kind is sure to go very hard, and the children have been given every care, but in spite of all we can do this kind trouble is beginning to show itself. I know cases too numerous of the children have been under nourished from infancy and have very little rallying power.

Late last night we had to send for the Doctor to see little girl who we thought could not possibly pull through the night. We managed to restore her, however, and had her partially recovered when he arrived.

I had him examine other cases which have been rather stubborn, with the above result.

We feel that with careful nursing and our present equipment we ought to be able to handle these without any serious results, but would like to fail, in any event, that everything possible had been done for them. There are more Pneumonia cases in our locality this year than in any former years, and Doctors and Nurses are kept very busy. In fact, are not able to keep up with the demands, outside help having been brought in.

Our own child, a girl of thirteen, was we hoped would write on her entrance this year; and who has been staying with a family in town until recently, the Public School, when visiting home during the week end, developed Scarlet Fever, and we have had to isolate her with an old child's room, i.e., one of the Infirmary rooms, she has barely been in two weeks, but as the regulations call for a six weeks' isolation, we cannot use this part of the building for fully a month yet. We are most anxious to prevent contact in any way.

We have amongst our staff, those who are very willing to take a share in the work of nursing, but unfortunately, one of our workers has broken down at the work, and the doctors have advised our immediate removal to hospital. Our kitchen matron has been called away on account of the outbreak of influenza here, and hope to fill these vacancies, but mean while the staff has quite all right. It is possible for them to do to care for the ordinary wants of the Institution.

We shall appreciate anything the Department can do to help out at this time.

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

My Dear Lord Bishop:

I beg leave to notify you that it is my intention to give up the Principalship of this Institution.

My decision in this respect is not a hasty one, but one which I have foreseen for quite a long while.

I am giving you a full three months' notice of my intention so that the M.A.O., the Department of Indian Affairs and yourself will not be driven to the necessity of making arrangements for my successor on short notice.

The work here during the interim will be carried on in the usual manner, and I shall do my utmost to have everything in as good order as possible by the end of the year.

It will be my aim, with the greatest care, to see that all liabilities are paid so as to leave no deficit at the year's end.

If a suitable successor is found and he desires to obtain a knowledge of the work of the management of the Institution, I am quite satisfied to do all I can to aid him in this both of finances and salary will not however come out of the funds of the school for the ensuing three months.

I have always felt, with careful management, that the present Institution could be made a centre from which would radiate a wide influence for the uplifting of our native people, thus preparing for a citizenship in this world and in the world to come, and I trust that under the good hand of God this expectation will be realized in the fullest extent.

A copy of this notice is being being mailed to the Department of Indian Affairs, to Mr. G.M. Maclean, the Secretary of the Native Alliance and the New Church Board.

Regretting that circumstances should have arisen that make this action on mine necessary, and assuring you of my desire still to advance the cause of the Indian people, wherever possible.

Yours very faithfully,

Geo. Pauw.

Dear Sir:

I write you with reference to our herd of Registered Brahman stock, now at our Institution here.

This herd has been selected with the greatest of care, or rather the foundation stock have, from some of the most noted herds in Canada.

Amongst them are stock tracing back three times to the world's Champion cow Lady Jane Sylvia. There are also the deep tracings of the Pontiac Syndicate and the Alberta.

I believe we have 27 that are or will register, besides about twelve or fourteen good grades.

The wintering of this stock is going to mean quite an expense to the school as a great deal of the feed will have to be imported; and since we are under a promise to the Department not to engage in the sale of milk, our income will be greatly lessened for the coming winter, making it unprofitable for us to keep such a large herd.

I feel that we could easily spare 20 head of the choicest of this stock. Some would be milch cows, some yearling heifers and some this spring's calves, and one young yearling bull.

All the stock from which these young animals have sprung have been Tuberculin tested, and the herd has always been free from abortion.

Going to our senior herd sire, King Bohe Champion, becoming too fat and heavy during last winter quite a number of our cows failed to become with calf early in the summer, but through importing a new bull and reducing the bigger bull in flesh we have virtually overcome this difficulty. Most of the cows have been in milk for nearly nine months however and, on this account are not making such a great showing, giving not more than half of what they would be giving under normal conditions.

While paying a visit to the Mohawk Institute near Brantford last week, Mr. Rogers, together with the Principal, Mrs. Boyce, expressed a great desire to go into the work of raising a good herd of this particular cattle, and said they would endeavour to get the consent of the Department as also to secure some financial aid towards the purchase of such a herd and felt that by co-operation of this kind the Institutions would benefit mutually.

If the Department could see its way towards some such arrangement I for my part should be ready to meet the Mohawk Institute with a reasonable figure as it would be possible for me to quote for enough to make up a full ear-load. I may add that all Pedigreed stock are transported at half cost.

Trusting that this suggestion may meet with your kind consideration.

Believe me,

Very faithfully yours,

Sir:

I beg to report the children from Gibson, Parry Island and Shawanacee visited the Chippewa Industrial school on the 10th inst.

I wish to state that I made a thorough inspection of the school and I am satisfied that the children are being well looked after. The whole of the staff is excellent and from my observation I would compare the management of the school as something near what is done in England and in Scotland in the boarding schools, by this I mean Private boarding schools such as Preparatory schools. The children appear happy and as I walked about the grounds I spoke to quite a number and it was a pleasure to me to notice how frank the children were in answering my questions.

I am convinced that it is not a matter of dollars and cents that keeps the Chippewa Industrial School in operation and I know by little actions which I see while I was there, that the love of God is in the hearts of the staff and by the kindness and actions of the children, it would appear to me that the staff is gradually imparting that same feeling into the children.

I found 55 boys and 36 girls—a total of 91 pupils in the school. 42 of these are in the senior room and the balance in the junior room. With the exception of Louise, who has been sick for some time but is kept isolated from the other pupils—although the medical officer states she is not a menace to the health of the other children—all the pupils appeared to be in excellent health and appeared well satisfied at the school. I visited the dining room at the time of one of the meals and found the pupils were obtaining sufficient wholesome food. It might be mentioned that whole milk is given to the pupils in generous quantities. During the month of August, the cow at the school gave 2784 quarts of milk, all of which was used for the pupils and staff.

SIX NATION PUPILS:

Particular attention was given to the 13 children recently sent to the school from the Six Nation agency. I had a private talk with each of them and not one made any complaints regarding the school or the treatment they were receiving from the staff. All of them were in good health. The vice principal stated that shortly after they came to the school he had some difficulty with two or three of the boys running away; but he located them quickly and has had no further trouble in that regard.

BUILDINGS:

A special report regarding the cottage for the vice principal—minor repairs to building—and complaints of the management regarding the heating system will be found on File 65-1-5.

GENERAL:

I found that the classroom registers are properly kept. Upon enquiry, I ascertained that the pupils have not practised fire drill. The vice principal, however, stated that he would make immediate arrangements to have this done regularly in future and Mr. Agent Godfrey promised to see that this was carried out.

Two of the pupils, Emily Donald and Harvey Black, are attending the high school in Chapleau. The school management arranges to have these children taken to the school and brought home each day. There are 9 pupils in the senior classroom who, it is expected, will try the Entrance Examination in June, 1926.

On the whole, I feel that this school should show further progress in the future. As noted above, there are now 91 children in the school. Mr. Agent Godfrey has some more in view in order to bring the number up to that for which grant is allowed. Mr. Godfrey gives the management every possible assistance and visits the school at least two or three times each week.

Ottawa, June 4, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

The Bishop of Moosonee, who was asked to furnish plans and specifications showing the style of building to be erected for the Chapleau Boarding School, has written giving particulars as to the cost and forwarded a photograph showing the building under construction, together with a sketch plan of the proposed additions, which will cost when completed about $7,000.

This year's supplementary estimates contain an item of $5,000 to assist in the completion of this building, as well as a per capita grant of $60 for each of 40 pupils.

It is unfortunate that the Bishop should have undertaken the construction of a building before submitting plans and specifications to the Department, as I fear the structure, if finished in accordance with the sketch plan, will be very unsuitable for a school, owing to the way it is laid out, and I would suggest that Mr. Ogilvie be asked to try to remedy some of the defects noticed in the plan.

The Bishop is going North and will not return till about August 15, and if proper plans could be prepared by that date, he would be in a position to call for tenders for the additions. Of course, no money can be paid at present, as there are no accounts before the Department, and as it will take nearly all the grant to pay for the additions, I think it would be well to hold onto the funds until the contract is under way and that he should be advised to the above effect.
Ottawa, June 6, 1907.

Mr. Awoye:

I would like you when at Chapleau to visit the new boarding school building and see what work has been done and what accommodation the present structure provides.

The Church authorities have submitted a sketch showing the proposed additions, a blue print of which is attached hereto. You will notice that the wing on the right will cut off all light from the main building on that side, while the addition in the rear will be most inconvenient, as the only entrance to the main building will be through the kitchen or the boys' and girls' lavatories or else they will have to go all round the building to the front door, which would cause great dirt and discomfort in the winter and wet season. It is, therefore, a question, whether it might be better to put up an entirely new building to meet the extra requirements instead of making a batch job of the present one.

You will ascertain whether a convenient site is available adjacent to the present building. I should also like you to ascertain what facilities there are for a reliable supply of water and drainage and how they propose to heat the building.

Mr. H. McClain Banting is the diocesan secretary at Chapleau and you might ask him to accompany you, and I would like you to make your report before going north.

Thank you.

Sir:

I beg to report that I visited the Boarding School at Chapleau Monday August 8th, and while there made a careful inspection of the site, and also measured drawing of the existing building, and have since prepared plans for the necessary extension to this School.

I had an opportunity of submitting the plans at Regina to Bishop Holmes, and am pleased to say that they are in every way satisfactory to him.

The plans, as you will observe, are complete except the Heating and plumbing. These details can be added to the plan later, as I will be at headquarters before they will require attention.

It is understood, that, the Bishop will have the personal oversight of the building while under erection, and as the construction will be similar to the other portion of the building, and as my time is very limited, I have not prepared specifications.

Should they, however, be required if you will send me a blueprint of the plan in the care of the Commissioner at Victoria, or to Winnipeg I will prepare them before returning to headquarters.

I will stop over at Chapleau on my return past and see the progress.
Ottawa, August 30, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Re Charlevoix Boarding School.

An addition is required to the building which has just been erected and Mr. Ogilvie has just sent in plans providing for such addition. It is almost too late in the season to carry out the work, even if approved of, but a kitchen is provided for at the rear of the main building in Mr. Ogilvie's plans, and in a letter received from Bishop Holmes, he says that the kitchen is needed at once.

I would, therefore, suggest that the Bishop be authorized to go on with the kitchen extension and in the meantime that Mr. Ogilvie should prepare specifications for the other additions, so that tenders could be called for or an estimate of the probable cost obtained.

The current year's estimates contain an item of $5,000 to assist in the completion of the building, and it is doubtful whether this amount will be sufficient to carry out Mr. Ogilvie's plans. However, there will be plenty of money for the kitchen extension.
Ottawa, September 4, 1907.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 27th ult. In further reference to the new boarding school building at Chapleau, and in reply I beg to say that a blueprint of Mr. Ogilvie's plan, showing the proposed enlargement of this building is being sent you under separate cover; but before you are authorized to proceed with the erection of the kitchen wing, which you wish to have built before the winter sets in, the Department will require an assurance from the Ontario Government that the school site will be granted your Diocese, as it is not disposed to go to any expenditure on buildings on land to which you have no valid title.

I would, therefore, suggest that you communicate with the Commissioner of Crown Lands for Ontario and find out upon what terms a title to the land in question will be given. In the meantime you should obtain an estimate of the cost of material and labour for the kitchen wing and forward the same to the Department, and as soon as the question of title is settled, you will be further advised.

I have the honour to be,
Right Reverend Sir,
Your obedient Servant,

J. L. McLean

Dear Sir—

I am simply in an awful fix over this Mr. Grillier and the men who supplied him the goods to complete the Indian School. In fact I don't know what to do.

As I explained previously, this man is a poor fellow who cannot afford to take large contracts and wait so long for his money. And the men who supplied him the material are dogging him all the time, and the consequence is, I am the one who gets the blame. I cannot see where I am to blame; I promised Mr. Scott I would look after the work, and see it was done right, this I did, and the work has been done, and done well, and something must be done or a lien will be put on the building.

This I should be very sorry to see, especially just at the present time.

Perhaps if the Bishop was here, he might enlighten us somewhat, but he will not be back before spring.

The school requires a better water service, the well formerly used, owing to the dry season, failed to supply them with water, and owing to the amount of rock at this place great difficulty has been experienced in going to the depth necessary to procure a sufficient supply for their use.

There is an abundant supply of water for other purposes in the river which passes within a few yards of the building. This however is not fit for use in the school owing to sewage being emptied into the river a short distance above from Chapleau.

I have instructed the Rev. Mr. Sowens to drive a well near the river in the hope of procuring a plentiful supply there which will be available at all times.

It will also be necessary to provide drainage from the kitchen sink to the rear of building.

Storm sash should also be provided for windows not now fitted with them, and also a porch to protect the rear door.

The exterior of stable should also be painted to prevent rapid deterioration of the building by the weather.

With respect to the accounts of the contractor I may say that I have gone into them very carefully and have issued a certificate for one thousand, one hundred and twenty-five dollars and forty-three cents ($1125.43) the amount due him.

It will be noted that Bishop Holmes has advanced two hundred and three dollars and fifty cents ($203.50) which amount it will be necessary to deduct from the contractor's cheque, and send cheque for this amount to the Rev. Mr. Sowens at Chapleau to replace the amount temporarily paid.

For the Deputy Inspector,

I beg to report that as instructed I proceeded to Chapleau and on Tuesday October 20th, made an inspection of the Indian Boarding-school there in company with the Indian Agent.

There has been erected in the rear of main building a substantial kitchen wing on stone foundation, which provides ample accommodation for the intended use on the ground floor, and a convenient school-room on the floor above.

In addition to the new wing very considerable necessary improvements have been made to the main building, such as alterations to stair-way, putting on a finishing coat of plaster over the entire main building (which had been previously been left in the rough coat), painting this building outside and inside, flooring and ceiling the attic and fitting up as a store-room.

A substantial stable has also been erected in connection with the school, also other outhouses and closets which were necessary for their health and convenience.

The work has been fairly well done, and the materials generally of fair quality, with the exception of a portion of the siding which is inferior and had not been properly seasoned before using.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to the Chapleau School which lasted from January 2nd to 4th, I went carefully into the requirements for this school for the current year. You will have before you the list of requirements presented to your Department through our General Secretary for all of our body's Indian Residential Schools, the Chapleau School included. In addition to those mentioned for the Chapleau School, my attention was directed during my visit to the following requirements:

1. The kiln-drying of the walls and furnishing of the woodwork of the interior and the renewal of the rough cast to the exterior of the main school building.
2. The provision of new tables and benches for the children's dining room.
3. The renewal of the fire brick in the base of the heating system.
4. A new gasoline engine for cutting wood.

The most urgent requirements of this school are, of course, (a) the extension of class-room space, (b) the building of a chapel, and (c) an implement shed. I was pleased to note that a new felt roof had been placed on the barn but regret the walls were not raised at the same time. It is, however, that provision has been made in your estimates for the current year to meet the requirements enumerated above and will be obliged if you will inform me at your earliest convenience if such is the case.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

In reply to your letter of January 19th, No. 65-1-5 relative to the repairs to the Boiler at the School this work was ordered done by Dr. Wesgate, and is not done to our satisfaction so the account I can not send in until such time as the Mechanic completes it.

Dr. Wesgate's statement saying that the Principal had informed me of the condition of the Boiler six weeks before his visit, this is a gross misstatement as I have a record of my visit called at the school over this winter, on the 2nd day of December and at that time the Vice Principal advised me that the boiler had been in this condition for some months but he had neglected to inform me and I criticized his action at the time in not advising me but he claimed he had overlooked it.

Dr. Wesgate did not try very hard to locate me as I was at my office every day that he was in Chapleau and he never came near my office but he did try to make me come out to the school immediately and which I had not the time to go even had I the inclination to Dr. Wesgate imagining that I must jump every time he says it and because things are not going just as smoothly at the school as they should I am not going out there to listen to his ravings against the staff and everybody in general as well as myself who am not responsible for the way things are going at the school.

I show Dr. Wesgate every courtesy but I have no intention of listening to his uncalled for remarks against myself and others because I can not recommend everything he suggests or because he resents my connection with the school.

I had already ordered the repairs for the boiler which had to be sent out for and which only arrived couple of days before I received your letter. Dr. Wesgate takes the excuse that the situation was critical to cover up if it was critical which it was not why did not the Principal advise before the expiration of months and it is becoming quite an ordinary thing for work to be ordered done at the school without my knowledge & which possibly I would not recommend.

When preparing the Estimates for the current year, I was aware that considerable repairs and replacements were necessary at the Chapleau Indian Residential School. $2,100 has been made available for this purpose and expenditures totalling this amount, with your approval, have already been authorized. The heating system was in such poor condition that it was necessary to have a competent steamfitter and plumber examine the plant with a view to determining what repairs were required. They are more extensive than anticipated. Tenders have been secured from the only two firms in Chapleau and the lowest quotation is $1400.

I believe the work should be undertaken, but I am not satisfied that the Department should meet the entire cost. I have discussed the matter with both Mr. Orr and Mr. Helean, who have been at the school when I visited it, and I believe there are two reasons why repairs and replacements of this kind are so costly at this school: First, the engineer cannot be well qualified, and Second, the number of breakages supports improper supervision of the boys during their off hours.

I shall be glad to have your instructions.

I have the honour to report the following in connection with the work which is in progress on the heating plant at the Chapleau Indian School.

When the Inspector made his report and the contract was awarded to Mr. Crichton, for the completion of the work as per the specifications of the Inspector on tearing down the damaged brick work it was found that the plates as ordered put in by the Inspector could not make the job a permanent one so the matter was taken up with the makers of the boiler and heating plant E. Leonard & Sons, and they stated the only safe and proper method was to put in Brick arch instead of the plates, and as the plates were thin and upon examination of them myself I readily saw that they would not stand the tremendous heat in the front of the fire box so did not let him put them in and as this was holding up the work I authorized him to put in a proper brick arch which he would guarantee and which with the cost of the large cast plates which he had ordered and were on hand he estimated at $40.00, my reason for authorizing this work was the absolute necessity of it and the fact that the man who was doing the brick work was brought in from Kenora and could not be again secured if let go and when receiving word or authorization from the Department it would cost much more to have the work done.

There was also some other small extra emergency work I had the boiler maker do while working on the boiler which could not be detected until the brick work was taken down.

Hoping my action in this matter will meet with your approval I beg to remain,

Your obedient servant,

There is also a tender on the closets he has quoted on 6 closets giving a price on two different kinds, and relative to this work in the original application for 2-5 seat closet sets in going over this again with Dr. Wagata, and owing to the fact that so much repair was needed and being done I pointed out to him that we could make 6 toilets do for this year or until later on and I asked Mr. Crichton to give me a price on these six and which is enclosed.

Relative to the cause of the bad condition of the heating plant it is solely to the fact that it has not been properly looked after by a Qualified person and left in charge of boys who do not understand or care whether the plant and equipment is damaged or not and the same applies to the damage to the boys toilets there apparently seems to be no one in charge of these boys while in the recreation room and they have a Matron in charge of them but she can not watch these boys and they smash and break things with no one to check them up, I hate to have to report this but the damage to equipment around this school seems to have no end and unless some better system applied I do not know where it will end.

There is supposed to be a qualified Engineer in charge of the mechanical plant but from observation I can not say much for his work but possibly he is worth all he gets as I can not see how they can get good men for these positions for the wages they pay, and in the end the Department is paying for these short comings and incompetency of these employees.

Mr. Jones who is in charge of the farm work and the outside machinery apparently seems to carry on well but he is not allowed to interfere with work inside but from observation he could look after the heating plant if allowed.

Dear Sir,

I have the honour to submit to you prices for school bells & extension ladder for the Indian school as per your letter No. 66-1-5 of Dec. 2nd, 1927.

When making an inspection of the school short time ago the matter of fire protection was brought strongly to my attention and it being just at the time of the Quebec disaster it was brought very strongly to our minds as to what would be the result at the school in case of fire, and upon testing out our water pressure we found that we could not get up sufficient pressure to be of any use for fire purposes.

After consulting the Engineer in charge at the school he thought that with slight changes in the piping from the intake to the pump and from the pump to the pressure boiler that we might possibly get more pressure, this change I authorized him to make which was done at only the cost of a few feet of pipe and riveting the labour being done by the school engineer, and although we secured some further pressure it is far from being sufficient to be suitable for fire protection as we can not get up pressure to force the water to the second story.

In view of the fact that protection is necessary and urgent I beg leave to recommend the purchase of another pressure pump which could be connected to the Fire main direct and to be used only in case of Fire or other emergency should the present pump fail at any time in the regular daily supply of pressure.

In this connection we would require an extra motor as there is an extra motor at the school which with slight repairs could be used for the fire pump.

Waiting your instructions I beg to remain,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Chapleau Indian Residential School, makes the following recommendations:

"A separate and direct telephone connection with Chapleau central should be established in case of fire. At present the call has to go from the school to another building and then to the telephone central.

The balconies at the north of the building should be provided with removable glass windows for winter use and screens for summer use. These balconies could thus be used as sun rooms and would be much more serviceable."

Chapleau April 23rd, 1928.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 65-1-5, of April 21st, relative to the installation of the telephone and connecting to the Chapleau central station I have gone carefully into the cost and the amount stated is the lowest figure that it could be installed for but by using No. 18 Gauge wire a saving of $25.00 would be made.

Regarding the existing service it is of no practical use as it is out of commission most of the time owing to it being only a ground line and the single wire from which it is operated is often broken strung on the high voltage electric lights lines when the Dynamo is working it is almost impossible to use it consequently they have very little connection with Chapleau and in cases of emergency have to drive in for the Doctor or other urgent messages, and for fire protection alone it would be a safeguard, and while we have the new fire pump installed at the school this would be of very little use outside the main building and no protection whatever to the Barns and other buildings which are situated some distance from the main building.

While the Phone system is not absolutely necessary as we have managed these number of years without it I feel owing to the small cost involved, and the staff offering to secure and erect the pole line that I should recommend the expenditure of the $250.00 which is the cost of the line using No. 18 wire.

Waiting your instructions in the matter I remain,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

I beg leave to report that owing to the dangerous condition of the pipes and lining of the Bake Oven at the Chapleau Indian School I found it necessary to order some immediate repairs to eliminate the danger of fire, the repairs are only temporary and it will require a complete new lining for the oven and complete set of fire bricks and lining for the fire box to put the bake oven in good shape.

In the junior classroom there are 10 double seats which are out of keeping with an institution of this kind. They should be replaced at an early date with 20 single seats. A plan was approved whereby a row of 7 seats could be secured by taking over a row of 7 seats which are too small for satisfactory use in the senior room. In this plan 7 new and larger seats should be procured for the senior room and the additional 13 new single seats for the junior room.

In one respect, however, the accommodation seems somewhat limited. I refer to the recreation rooms provided for the boys and girls. In discussing this matter with the Principal, Canon Vale, he pointed out that the difficulty could be overcome by using the basement present used for a chapel, for a recreation room. This would provide ample space for outdoor games as well as for organized physical culture. This suggestion would involve the addition of a new chapel. The Principal's suggestion was with my approval. Canon Vale also suggested that for various reasons exits should be provided from the basements. He pointed out that this could be accomplished by changing two windows into two doors. His plan seems worthy of adoption.

There is at present a lack of outdoor games for the girls. Some attention should be given to this matter. Some slides of the type at present found on city playgrounds would be very much appreciated.

Ottawa, July 9, 1930

Sir,

I visited the Chapleau Indian Residential School and met the Principal, Colton Vale. I was very favourably impressed by his earnestness and interest in the school work. He is of a quiet easy-going manner with a pleasing personality and is working hard to bring the school back to the standard it had reached a few years ago. The buildings and equipment are well cared for and in good condition. The interior of the school is kept very tidy and spotlessly clean. There are about 25 remaining during the holidays - looked real well, happy and enjoying themselves. Owing to the nature of the land, which is principally bush and rock, very little is being done along agricultural lines. There are 10 acres sown in oats, which is cut green for feed; hay has to be purchased. There is an excellent garden and is sufficient to provide potatoes and vegetables all winter.

The stock consists of 17 pure bred Holstein cows, six head of young stock, a pure bred bull, three pigs, two young sows and a male for breeding purposes, two teams of heavy horses, a driver and about one hundred hens. All the milk and butter produced is used by the pupils and staffs. Dr. Sheahan reports the health of the pupils very good and free from tuberculosis.

The barn has not been completed to provide a hay mow. This work should be done, if the necessary funds are available right away. Hay and oats for feed have to be stocked outside all winter, reducing the feed value very considerably. Principal Vale is most anxious that this work be completed this fall to take care of the winter's feed, while in the present climate is...

Dear Sir,

Your letter of Sept. 3rd, has been received and we are sorry there was a misunderstanding in quoting price on Caroline Engine outfit for cutting wood.

Owing to the fact that no dimensions were given we inferred that the saw itself was not required; therefore we quoted an extremely low price for engine and frame only at $250.00.

This outfit was procured from the United States and we are sorry there was some delay in obtaining it.

Owing to the fact that our quotation to you was addressed under the name of Rev.A.J.Dale instead of Rev. A.J.Vale, the quotation was not connected when order was received from Ottawa. You have not yet stated what size saw is required but we believe you will find a 30" saw the best and most serviceable for your work. This can be supplied for $85.00.

Saws in 20 and 25 inch can be supplied at a little lower price. We shall await definite instructions before placing the order for the saw.

We regret the misunderstanding and shall be glad if you will refer to our file R 263 when replying.

Sir:

Your letter with reference to the work performed by Messrs. Cannetto & Knight of Sudbury at the Chapleau School has been referred to this Department by the Honourable Minister of Public Works for attention.

In reply to your letter I beg to say that up to the present time it has been impossible to pay the accounts submitted by this firm for the work done at the Chapleau School. The Department of Justice have ruled that where work is being carried out on a percentage basis, receipted accounts for materials, and also labour returns must be furnished before payment can be made. In connection with this work, it would appear from recent correspondence that this firm has not the funds available with which to pay the accounts for materials until such time as the Department has reimbursed them for the materials purchased and the labour performed.

With a view to making an early settlement of their account, a letter has today been sent to Mr. Godfrey, Chapleau, instructing him to pay the accounts for the materials supplied, and to forward receipted accounts to the Department, and it is hoped that in this way the matter of payment to Messrs. Dear Sir,

With further reference to our conversation over the telephone regarding the error in connection with the purchase of the toilet valves for the school. I wish to explain, at my request, Messrs Wolfe and Collins of Chapleau sent for six valves. On their delivery the account was sent in to the Department. When I tried to install them I found they were not the correct type. I had not specified they were to be the Automatic kind.

We returned them and now have received the Automatic kind but unfortunately the price is higher for these. I have therefore requested them to send in the complete account for these and a copy of the amount formerly paid on the others so it may be deducted from this total now being sent.

I regret making the error and hope this explanation will make the transaction clear.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of February 5th 1932 and No I-1-5, I beg to state I also received one from our Secretary Rev. Dr. Westgate of the Bible House Winnipeg Man., urging me to take such action as required to meet your request. This I gladly do. I have consulted the Indian Agent, Mr. T.J. Godfrey of Chambly in regard to our Fire Escape. It is of the Ladder type and is not completed to the ground. We both agree it is not of the best type but cannot well be improved at the present time. We would like it improved when the weather will permit of it. I would like to see the Ladder replaced with the Spiral Chute type.

In the meantime I am doing what I can with the children in the matter of the FIRE DRILL and will continue to do so. The Indian Agent and I agreed this was the best under the present circumstances.

I am yours very sincerely

[Signature]
